element_texts.text:
1
1862 The severity of the winter the high floods and deep snows had financially ruined a large class of our population, and a tremendous mining excitement springing up in the Salmon River Country; up Snake Run in Washington Territory. and in consequence thereof a large portion of the laboring population drifted off in that direction in hopes to make up their losses by a streak of good fortune in the mines. Like most gold excitements this proved to be a humbug to a great extent. Yet extensive & rich mines were opened. Cities & towns built up, and a dense mining population crowded in & filled up the country drained by the Columbia River and even penetrated the Region beyon the summit of the Rocky Mountains. Prospecting the Rivers & their tributaries for gold, searching for choice valley for farming, locating sites for towns, and daily contending with the hostile Indians always to be found in way to check & harass and impede & annoy the pioneer advance of civilization. I had contemplated going in that direction myself and try & make up my

losses, but was prevailed upon by friends to stay and be a candidate for Co. Clerk & was triumphantly elected when the election day came round and I soon entered upon the duties of the office. The labor light, pay good, and the great objection being that it required a person to be on hand at all times during business hours, hence very confining to one who is as fond of outdoor life as I am; The summer gradually wore away, and winter was upon us, mild & wet. The Legislature which meet in Sept disorganized Umpqua County & attached it to Douglas and thus all the Umpqua Valley is now embraced in Douglas as the act took efect in July 1863, and it became my duty to remove the County property to Roseburg the County seat of Douglas County and surrender it up with proper authorities which was done on the 5 of the month, and by the act of the Legislature aforesaid I was thus Legislated out of a portion of the term for which I had been elected. A.W.S. Land office being at Roseburg, I hired out and

2
worked for the Register and Review about 2 months and was out of employment for the time being. About the middle of Sept 1863 I submitted a proposition to the citizens of Roseburg to explore the Cascade Range of Mountains up the North Umpqua River and cross over the Summit easterly from a point on the N. fork of the N. Umpqua where some little mining has been done during the last year and where a few men at at present at work to the intersection of the old Fremont trail running from the Dalles to Klamath Lake: The proposition was accepted and with an expedition of four I set out on Wednesday Sept 16 1863 and followed the main Wagon Road from Roseburg up Deer Creek Easterly about 6 miles thence North Easterly by a wagon road through a hilly oak timbered country about ten miles and put up for the night at Mr. Leonard Buells an enterprising farmer in Mount Scott precinct. Abraham Jones, one of the men was thrown from his horse today and was considerably bruised in consequence of his foot hanging in the stirrup but his hurts were not serious Walking made all hands foot sore

and all hands were glad to stop. Thursday Sept 17 1863 Set out from Mr. Buells early in the morning and found the North Umpqua River about 100 yds wide and proceeded up through a handsome & fertile valley for about five miles to the house of Mr. J.V. Bradly who is the highest settler on the Umpqua River. From this point our route was along the River Easterly by a very good trail. with not much bottoms for about four miles to Rock Creek a rapid and turbulent stream of about 30 feet wide with grass at its mouth and here we camped at about one oclock P.M. The afternoon was passed away in making a tent and in fishing. trout were found to be quite abundant in the rapids along the River and some fine ones were caught. Friday Sept 18 1863 Starting out on the miners trail up the bank of the River. we left the margins of the prairie a few rods above and entered the thick heavy green timbered forest and after travelling about 4 miles the trail was

3
found to leave the River and lead up a spur of the mountain to the left, thence along a ridge for about 2 miles when we descended to a stream about 6 feet wide flowing into the South Umpqua a short distance to the right of us  Crossing this little stream the trail led directly up the spur of a mountain on the opposite side and on an along a high ridge for about 5 1/2 miles to the head of a small spring branch on the right of the trail.  its waters running off to the right or southerly to the N. Umpqua.  It had been represented to us that good grass could be obtained at this place, and we were disappointed in not being able to find any at all.  however we were obliged to camp for the night but our horses fared poorly.  A little Pea vine growing in the heavy timber was all the feed the animals could obtain     Saturday Sept 19 1863 Our course was Easterly on the trail which followed a high dividing Ridge which soon became rocky boulders and broken Basalt thickly scattered over the surface, with deep canyons on each side.  after travelling about 11 miles, we found

4
up stream, crossing several small tributaries and we were obliged to camp for the night without grass for the horses  The mountains are high and rocky & very heavily timbered. the travel to the mines above has as a general thing been confined to the old Indian trails. that lead over the high ridges, where to say the least very poor trails have been made, to their fisheries on some stream, thence to their hunting grounds in the mountains, then to their fisheries again or to more distant hunting grounds in the far off interior  Saw a few deer but found them to be very wild.  killed several grouse, but failed to get any shots at larger game
Sunday Sept 20 1863
About 3 miles this morning brought us to a stream coming in from N.W. and about 10 feet wide, and a little grass growing in bunches along the margin.  we concluded to camp and give our horses the benefit of what little there might be found in the vicinity  It rained and was quite unpleasant in the P. M.  Crayfish a species of small red lobster abounds in all the streams and a large quantity of them were caught and boiled in a Camp kettle

that the ridge which we had been following came to an abrupt termination, and that the trail wound its way down over broken rocks to the North fork of the North Umpqua River, and we soon found ourselves on the bank below.  This stream unites with the main stream a short distance below, and from the spur just before we began the descent we could see the main Canyon of the North Umpqua for a distance of 15 or 20 miles up Stream in a course about S. E.  Both streams appear to run through deep canyons, and are filled with rapids & cascades. The N. Fork of the N. Umpqua is a stream of about 50 feet wide and flows over a rocky bed, and upon the stream a few miles above is where the limited amount of mining has been done.  Our trail led us up this Stream in the left side about one mile to a perpendicular fall of 8 feet, where the stream falls over a solid formation of red granite. About 3 miles further

5
miners -- It appears to be more plenty upon the bars or on and near the surface in the loose sand  A few quartz boulders are found upon the stream, but Basalt predominates, with scattering granite  A little feed for animals was to be found scattering through the timber and we turned them out and put up for the day and were kindly and hospitably entertained by the miners
Tuesday Sept 22 1863
Did not leave this camp today  The country having been thoroughly explored and prospected from the settlements on the River below to this point.  and the prevailing opinion of all who have any knowledge of this part of the Cascade Range, is that the main Summit between the waters of the N. Umpqua River and the Willamette River, is a high divide running Easterly from this locality, in a direct course to the main summit of the Cascades, and that said summit could be reached from here in about one day, hence the proposition to explore the Country to the Eastward from this particular point to the Des Chutes River and the Dalles and California trail on the opposite or east side.  This

and eaten with a keen relish. It was amusing to see the men wade in the water to catch those animals.  Hamblin & Davenport were for two or three hours in the water two and sometimes as deep as 3 feet armed with sticks in search among the rocks for their game.  water cold, and men wet from head to foot.  Boiled lobsters were heartily eaten by all but was a new dish for all except myself
Monday Set 21 1863
Had an early start.  trail rough and at one and one half miles came to another 8 feet perpendicular fall over a ledge of gray granite, and at about 5 miles further the stream divided into two forks or prongs of nearly the same width.  We followed the trail which led us up the left hand fork and at about one quarter of a mile further we came to the miners cabins where we found John Easton, Ths Shrum, George Kerns James Fordyce and D. L Watson engaged in gold mining.  and by hard work it was found that they were making about $3 per day.  the gold being very fine and is termed "drift" gold by

6
from others as well as my own personal knowledge of the Country beyond:  I soon made up my mind that the main Summit of the Cascade Range must be much farther to the Eastward than the miners in this vicinity generally believed. The prevailing opinion among the miners was that we could reach the summit by a direct ridge in one day.  and from my own knowledge of the Country beyond I was satisfied that we could reach the trail where our expedition would terminate.  from the summit in one day without great effort. and thus the general opinion was at once fixed that we could reach the trail in two days and return in two more.  Thus Consuming four days from this Camp to the trail and back  Notwithstanding the miners all appeared to believe that the trip could be made in 4 days.  yet they recommended that we take 5 days provisions.  but making an estimate of what I believed the distance to be I found it necessary to start with breadstuffs enough to last us 16 days:  So our preperations were soon began for an early start tomorrow morning. The mountains being so rough and rocky and so destitute

information was found to be the firm opinion of all who claimed to have any knowledge of the Country, and as there was no variety of opinion, in regard to the summit ridge and main divide, therefore reliance was placed in the correctness of the opinion:  But after all agreeing upon the favorable route I was not quite prepared to believe that the main summit of the Cascade Range of mountains, was quite so near to us. and my opinion was based upon a former knowledge obtained while travelling along the East side of said Range in 1860 during which time I acquired a very correct idea of all the Snowy peaks and other noted Land marks.  always to be seen along and near the summit of the mountains:  During that year {1860) I learned the fact that the main summit of the Range is generally from 4 to 10 miles from the Eastern base, and that from the foot of the mountains on the East side it is not over 15 miles to the Dalles & California trail where we expect to terminate our expedition.  After considering all the information I could obtain

7
upon the opposite side, and steered in an easterly Course as near as the general character of the Country would permit.  A little afternoon we found a deep canyon before us which it became necessary to cross  At the bottom we found a rapid little stream of 6 feet wide flowing south.  After crossing the Canyon we had very nice travelling for a few miles and went into Camp quite early on a small branch where we happened to kill a deer which added to the luxuries of camp life  Davenport has been unwell for two or three days, and is worse today.  is badly afflicted with bloody flux, Country rough today.  Saw many quartz boulders scattered promiscuously over the highlands.  also other indications of minerals and also Copper Sulphpherets
Thursday Sept 24 1863
Davenport is much worse today. is not in a condition to travel but he was in favor of trying it rather than delay the expedition.  About 1/4 mile brought us to a rapid little stream of ten feet wide running south where much crystalized Quartz rock is to be found.  We cross this stream and ascend a high and

of grass, that our horses had suffered from the want of feed, and the country to the Eastward being of a similar character or worse, we decided to send our animals back to the settlement by a couple of the miners who were about to return. The animals had been a great hindrance so far and the men highly pleased with the prospect of being relieved from them and were more than willing to pack their blankets and grub on their backs:  Our Outfit selected was a small tent, one blanket for each person, three guns, a camp axe, and frying pan & a couple of tin cups. Our horses were sent below and everything was in readiness for an early Start into a rough mountainous region never before explored
Wednesday Sept 23 1863
D. L. Watson started out with us, thus making a Company of five, a nice and convenient little Company for mountaineering  Our packs were put up and bidding good bye to the hospitable miners we set out.  we crossed the creek a little below the camp and ascended the mountain

8
A short distance through heavy timber this morning and we came to quite a high bold ridge which it became necessary to cross. and from the summit of which we had one of those magnifficent mountain views so common to the Oregon Mountaineers.  Diamond Peak a high Snowy Mountain. lay N. W of us and is situated on the Summit ridge at the N. side of the head of the middle fork of the Willamette River, and another snowy Butte lying S. E. and near the head of the Umpqua River and Rogue River  also several other peaks and rocky craters and cones along the summit which I readily recognized, which proved at once that I was much nearerunderlined correct in my estimates than the miners.  From these developements it was  certain we would not reach the summit for several days  A rock chimny or crater directly to the east of us and plainly visible from the trail beyond the mountains will be our guide for the present  Decending on the east side down into a deep timbered canyon to a stream about 8 feet wide running N. to the Willamette River and camped under a thick grove of large

steep mountain on the opposite side, finding high bush huckleberries common to the mountainous regions. in Great profusion and very ripe and delicious.  Much time was lost in picking berries, and while thus delayed we killed several grouse.  On the top of this mountain and on the eastern slope we found some open land, and descending on the opposite side to a spended little prarie of 40 or 50 acres through which we discovered an Indian trail. quite plain running in a course of N. W. & S. E., this trail did not exactly lead in the direction we desired to go, but followed it a mile or two and found it making too much Southing we left to our right and passing a few small spring branches we camped for the night having travelled about 6 miles.  Davenport being too sick to travel further.
Friday Sept 25 1863
Davenport is no better, but is in good spirits and proposes to make a short distance today being strongly impressed with the belief that he will be better tomorrow:

9
I suppose we was downstream about 2 miles and found it to be but one Continuous rapid and cascades all the way.  its General Course about due North.  Granite, Basalt, Conglomerate, Sand Rock, Quarts, and spar was every where visible.  the day was a dark and dismal one.  rained at intervals all day. At a point about one mile be low Camp, where the stream run through a gorge with perpendicular rock on one side, and a sloping rock, steep at an angle of a little more than 45º on the opposite side:  we found it impossible to pass this place.  only by creeping along the sloping rock on the left at a point about one hundred feet above the stream which looked practicable.  However before we had quite passed the rock it was found to be more dangerous than we had at first considered.  Being somewhat in advance of Hamlin, and walking carefully, with my gun in my right hand and clinging to the rock wherever I could find any place to cling to, and the blades of grass which occasionally appeared.  for it was

hemlocks. Davenport being much worse than in the morning  We saw several deer today and killed one. Davenports case has assumed a serious and dangerous character.  We did not make over 3 miles to day.  we had a very nice camping ground, but was rendered unpleasant by heavy rain in the P.M.
Saturday Sept 26 1863
Last night was stormy and blustering.  rained in torrents all night.  Davenport worse; and we commenced restricting him to a light diet and administering copious drafts of hemlock tea  We found it impracticable to move to day and therefore lay in Camp. This morning Mr Watson, finding their opinions as to the Summit of the mountains, to be so far from the facts, concluded to return to the mining camp.  We could not prevail upon him to continue with us.  we were sorry to part with him.  he left early on his return  Hamlin and myself explored the stream for some distance below. and Jones remained to take care of Davenport

10
From the highlands back we had seen a small prairie on the high mountain before us in a course about S.E. we therefore steered a S.E. course up the mountain. Steep and brushy and very wet and in about a mile and a half we saw daylight through the thick timber which proved to be the prairie referred: It had just commenced storming furiously again and as we stepped out to the margin of the timber we saw three deer standing together under a lone fir not far away & we fired upon them and had the satisfaction of killing them all. As we reached a higher elevation it was found to be very much colder than down in the canyon and in fact the rain is much mixed with snow and the storm appearing to increase and everything generally very disagreeable we did not consider it prudent to go farther at present so seeking the best camping ground visible we concluded to camp and wait for the storm to subside: There was no timber except green fir, scarcely a dry stik was to be found anywhere however we soon had a fire and pitched our tent and got Davenport

certain that a false step of any kind would send a fellow to the bottom, which might be a dangerous fall:  The rock was wet and wherever the dirt appeared upon its surface was exceeding slippery:  and before I had passed to a place of safety, my finger hold gave way and I fell and at once found myself on my back head downwards and sliding down the rock towards the stream below at a frightful rate.  I expected to have my brains dashed out on the boulders below, but happened to strike the stream where the water was about 3 feet deep & no boulders for about ten steps? above or below.  I was bruised up considerable but not hurt seriously:  My gun was found in the stream at full cock with the cap gone 
Sunday Sept 27 1863
Large quantities of rain fell during the night.  Davenport was more comfortable than he had been for a day or two.  was very weak, but was in favor of starting and going a short distance  Everything was very wet, but it did not rain as we set out but commenced very soon afterwards

11
Monday Sept 28 1863
A more unpleasant night is seldom ever passed by mountaineers or any other class of people.  the wind roared through the gorges and canyons and over the ridges the atmosphere was soon too cold for rain, hence the falling elements was changed into snow  It was with much difficulty that we managed to keep our fire burning during the night  Davenport was so badly exposed that I feared the Consequence.  this morning the snow was about 4 inches deep, and still falling.  No prudent man would move camp in such a storm unless in case of extreme emergency  We therefore concluded to lay over for the day and make ourselves as comfortable as the State of the weather would permit.  The storm continued until about 3. P.M. when it subsided and a thick fog eveloped the whole country.  At Sundown the fog partially cleared away.  the snow nearly a foot deep.  Game appeared plenty in this vicinity.  many deer tracks were seen in the snow near camp and several grouse were killed

under it and Hamlin volunteered to get the wood for the day and night if Jones and myself would prepare our venison and roast the ribs for our dinner. Our meat was soon roasting before the fire but the storm increasing in violence so that it became necessary to build a shelter over the fire to keep the rain from putting it out. this was done by building a Brush house as it is termed over the fire. from a ridge pole laid into two forks and the Brush roof made sloping each way and thus much rain was kept out of the fire and consequently fire easier kept up. The day wore away gradually but the rain and snow increased. Our tent was small and open at the ends and only a partial protection: night set in.  the cold winds, snow & rain was continually beating in upon us. We passed an uncomfortable night. Our fire was kept up all the time. no one unless it was poor Davenport got any sleep - The night passed away drearily and never was the appearance of morning looked forward to more anxiously.

12
surrounding mountains for many miles in every direction. The main summit of the Cascades could be traced for a distance of not less than 60 miles in a N. & S. course and the high dividing grounds between the North Umpqua and the Willamette Rivers could be plainly seen some 15 to 20 miles South of us having  a much more favorable appearance than the region of country which we were now in. I would have struck off in that direction but it would been deviating too far from our indicated course to make that much Southing  until the mountains had been crossed in an easterly course. The following Snowpeaks or peaks of perpetual snow were visible from this point viz Mt Jefferson N.5º E    Three Sisters N.20º E    Diamond Peak N.40º E    Mt McLaughlin S - also a high unnamed and unknown snow peak S. 25" E and about 20 miles distant. I became familiar with all these snowy peaks in 1860 and the knowledge then obtained I find to be of great value to us upon this expedition. We make the descent from here

and although we were having an unpleasant time, yet were living well
Sept 29}. Davenport appears much better this morning, so much so that we now believe him in a fair way to recover  Last night was cold and ice froze in the pools of water near camp so that no water could be had except snow water.  the sun rose bright with a clear sky overhead. We set out in an easterly course and upon  the summit of the Ridge about 1/4 mile from camp we found the snow considerable deeper.  from this point descend down into another deep canyon to a rapid rocky stream of 15 feet wide running North to the Wilamette  Crossing this stream and ascending the mountain on the opposite side for about 2 miles when we reach another Summit running N. & S. with a canyon East of us.  The snow on this Summit is over a foot deep and and the thick evergreen timber appears in places to be completley roofed over:  following this ridge southerly for about a half mile we ascended a rocky eminence where we had a fine view of the surrounding

13
It has been falling from the evergreen trees all day and sometimes in large masses in sufficient force to bury a man if he chance to be in the way. In many places we were obliged to pick our way carefully to avoid the falling snow as it fell in perfect avalanches in certain places breaking the limbs clear from the trees on its descent.  we were often exposed but escaped without our being buried up much. Wednesday Sept 30 1863 Our easterly course carried us directly up the mountain on the East side of the stream and from the top we followed a high snowy ridge in a course nearly East for about 8 miles when we found the ridge to trend to the south with a deep canyon before us; we descended to the bottom by a long and torturous route winding down the mountain and found a stream at the bottom about 15 feet wide flowing North and as it was somewhat past noon we concluded to camp for the night.  had no water except snow water since leaving camp this morning until we went into camp on this creek

Easterly down through rough & broken timbered ground and finally camped upon a stream 25 feet in width with a heavy volume of water rushing furiously along in its course N.W. This is probable the main branch of the Middle fork of Willamette and takes its rise in the snowy mountain nearest south of us. The snow is all off in the canyon and is melting fast on the mts. Nearly all the streams crossed today have all the indications peculiar to gold country and we have not doubt but this region of country abounds in gold sufficient to pay and justify mining. A little juniper on the ridges was noticed today, but fir spruce & hemlock is the principal timber. Saw several deer today & their tracks were numerous in the snow most everywhere also saw a bear track, several wild cat tracks, and a jackass rabbit track. It has been pleasant today rather warm walking. Snow about a foot deep on the ridges but none in the valleys

[lithograph covering page 14 transcribed on following page]

[text identifying lithograph]
Stanley del             Sarony Major & Knapp Liths 449 Broadway NY

this afternoon. The day has been warm. the snow is off the trees and the ground bare on the south side of the mountains. We saw some deer and a few Elk tracks in the snow today. Davenport is fast recovering and is in his usual good spirits as all hands are,  yet much grumbling is heard in regard to the ignorance of the North Umpqua miners in regard to the country East of them and the Cascade Mountains generally. Thursday Oct 1 1863 We commenced the ascent of the mountain on the East side of the creek at an early hour this morning and was pleased to find a high ridge leading off Easterly towards the main summit and which we reached in the P.M. having travelled about 12 miles; This was the point we had long and anxiously been looking forward to and as we were pretty tired we camped for the night on the summit ridge in 12 inches of snow; We found the snow deeper and deeper as we neared the summit and from appearance we judged it had been about 18 inches deep during the recent storm. We killed a very nice fat

14
deer today, saw several and vast amount of tracks in the snow as well as a few Bear tracks and the tracks of the large Porcupine peculiar to the N.W. coast of North America, but which are seldom found farther South than Puget Sound. The track was in the form of a Raccoon track but of about the size of little Bear tracks. Upon reaching this main summit we considered our journey nearly at an end, for a short days travel will take us to the Des Chutes River and from there the Dalles and Klamath Lake trail can easily be reached. Hemlock and spruce is the principal timber along the summit  and we gathered a large quantity of hemlock boughs for a bed and plenty of dry wood being convenient we soon had all the preparations for passing a comfortable night. Friday Oct 2d 1863 Last night was very cold and this morning the snow which was wet and sloppy yesterday was frozen so solid that we could easily walk on top of it. A course along the summit North Easterly for about one and a

15
from us, which valley or level appeared to extend off S.S.W. for at least 20 miles, with occasionally a small lake visible. After about 2 miles from the summit we came upon ground nearly level and open timbered land with a fine pulverized pummice stone soil, with a thick growth of Black Pine timber but no brush or grass of any kind. In about 8 miles we found ourselves upon the West fork of Deschutes River about 30 feet wide running N.E. and draining a little valley recently referred to. Des Chutes is a French name and signifies falls.  and its correct interpretation is the "The Falls River" and was laid down as Fall River on most of the early maps of the country. It rises in the Cascade Mts. and is formed by the numerous streams flowing to the East from said Range and between the Upper Klamath Lake on the South and the Columbia River on the North. Its source is about opposite the head of Rogue River and its general course is about due North along the Eastern base of the Mts. and after pursuing its course about 180 miles empties into the Columbia River about 15 miles above Dalles City. We followed down stream

quarter miles brought us to a rocky eminence from which we have another splendid view of the country in each direction. As many as 20 beautiful little lakes upon each side along and near the summit were in full view, ranging from 1/4 to 1 mile in extent, while all the snowy peaks previously mentioned were to be seen looming up magnificently far above the tops of the surrounding country. The curious formed crater which has been our guide when visible for several days is situated on the range about 3 miles to the north of us; While a high and steeple shaped rocky peak shooting up hundreds of feet above its neighboring mountains stands about S. of us about 25 miles away. From this position you can overlook the low and level pumice stone plains between the Cascade and Blue Mts. described in my journal of Sept 1860 and through which the trail towards which we are making our way passes in its N & S. course between the Columbia River and Klamath Lakes. We made our way down the eastern slope, gradual towards a narrow valley laying a mile or

16
plains filled with numerous flocks of Geese and ducks. The Snakes Indians are sometimes to be found infesting this region of the country and from this time until we cross back over the mountains on our return it becomes necessary to use a little precaution so in selecting a camp ground we picked upon as secluded a place as convenient under a thick clump of large spruce trees & gathered a large quantity of dry wood, and was thus prepared for a cold night. Saturday Oct 3 1863 Last night was one of those clear, cold and heavy frosty nights so common in this region of country. Ice froze to a considerable thickness in the swamp near by; Although we had fully discussed the question of danger during the evening; yet all hands kept cool and in fact were nearly froze out this morning, however we set out early East over the level  pummice stone plains scattering yellow & black pine no brush or grass or vegetable matter. Country nearly level and at about 8 miles we came to the East fork of the Deschutes a stream about 40 feet wide and like that of yesterday with small and

upon the left Bank about one mile and crossed over water opposite side on a Beaver dam on to narrow bottoms of Rich meadow & swamp land. alternating Beaver sign is plenty, their cuttings are to be seen everywhere, trees from 3 to 10 inches in diameter are to be seen all through the woods, cut down and the branches neatly trimmed off and dragged away to their dams ; In one place their ingenuity was beautifully displayed: a tree had fallen and lodged against another, and they had repeatedly cut off sticks of two or three feet in length until the tree was compelled to fall back the other way, over a dozen cuts had been taken off in this manner before the tree had fell: another similar tree had lodged and had been abandoned after cutting off some half dozen lengths ; we camped on the East side of the stream about a mile or two distant in the margin of a  large swamp extending to the stream and terminating a few rods below us in a large  marsh, with small openings of water to be seen in numerous

11
that all hands were unanimous in favor of returning by the middle fork of the Willamette although a much greater distance yet as there was a good trail from the Des Chutes river to the Settlements it was thought to be best and easiest route. Knowing that the old emigrant route by the Middle fork passed over the southern base of Diamond Peak we laid our course N. 62º W for that mountain with a view of keeping the same until the road was found; and after travelling about 4 miles over the disagreeable pumice stone we came to the East Fork of the Des Chutes again and camped. It was found necessary to reduce our rations somewhat tonight but no fears are entertained for the future. Sunday Oct 4 1863 Another severe cold night, bright and clear days and cold frosty nights prevail set out a little after daylight in our course for Diamond Peak, and at about 10 miles we intersected an old Indian trail, running very nearly on our course, we followed this trail about 2 miles and intersected the Old Emigrant Road at the crossing of the West fork of the Des Chutes.

narrow bottoms of grass land upon each side, an abundance of Beaver sign was also to be found upon this stream; We soon crossed over & in about 4 miles further we intersected the old trail where our expedition was to terminate. We reached here at 3 P.M. and according to our estimate had travelled 134 miles from Roseburg. At the place of intersection we peeled the bark smoothly from a black pine by the side of the trail on the west side, upon which we wrote the names of our party, their residence, and the object of the expedition, the distance from Roseburg &c and then prepared for our return. To encourage the men as much as possible while in the Mts. I had promised them the choice of routes by which to return 1 By the dividing ridge between the N. Umpqua and the Willamette 2 By the old Emigrant road by the Middle fork of the Willamettte 3 By Klamath Lake to Rogue River, and upon taking the sense of the company in regard to the matter, it was found

18
horses in Feb 1860 and from which point I was forced to return to the Big prairie below on the account of the deep snow. We continued down and camped on a stream at the lower edge of what is know as the Pine Woods, having travelled about 20 miles. Thursday Oct 6 1863 Continued down and met a Band of Cattle owned by Marion Martin of Lane Co. Ogn. who was on his way to the mining regions on John Days River. Rather late in the season to drive Cattle through this country but if the weather remains favorable for a few days until the summit is crossed no danger from storms need be anticipated. Wednesday Oct 7 1863 Stopped at noon at the Big Prairie no one at home at Sanfords the only ranch but we managed to get inside and found plenty to eat and cooked us a square meal and proceeded down River and camped at Point Lookout. Thursday Oct 8 1863 Rained hard much of the time today; we camped after

A short distance back Davenport picked up a small and very neatly executed piece of embroidery which had been torn off from some kind of a garment usually worn by ladies; No white women had been through this region since the Emigration of 1855, consequently it was lost or thrown away by some Indian, who had brought it from the white settlements or had taken it from the person of some unfortunate white lady who had been killed. Our route is now upon the old road to the settlements.  we soon found that a train of Pack animals had been over this route and also that considerable work had been done on the trail during the past summer - We camped at a point on the summit near the edge of the snow on Diamond Peak. Passing several small lakes, and one commonly called Crescent Lake which is about 6 miles in length. Monday Oct 5 1863 We soon passed the main summit and descended what is known as the summit Mountain to the point where I tied up my

19
near Hauley's at the foot of the Calipooia Mts on the North side. Monday Oct 12 1863 Passed over the mountain by the "Scott trail" and stayed all night at John Scotts at "Scotts  Valley." Tuesday Oct 13 1863 Our course towards Roseburg tooks us through Oakland in the Calipooia Creek and we camped in the Cammas Swale. Wednesday Oct 14 1863 Arrive at Roseburg having been absent 29 days and travelled 300 miles 75 of which had never been previously explored. The principal object of the expedition was to explore and ascertain the practicability of a route for a wagon Road or pack trail from the Mines in the N. Fork of N. Umpqua in an East course across the mountains. By the route travelled we had many high Mountains and tremendous deep canyons to contend with, much of which could been avoided by a route 15 miles further south, and even that

travelling a few miles & caught some very nice trout and killed a pheasant or two. Friday Oct 9 1863 Did not start out until late and when we reached the settlement at Butte Disappointment we put up at the old Gordon Ranch now occupied by his son in law one Mr. Hammit. Saturday Oct 10 1863 A mile or two from here we was to cross the middle fork to the South side, had considerable sport after a deer at the River. He was chased by two hounds and crossed the River several times near us and was finaly shot as he was swimming down past to avoid the dogs. Passed through the settlement of Pleasant Hill and camped on the Coast fork. Sunday Oct 11 1863 Followed up the valley of the Coast fork and camped

that route would probably prove impracticable for a wagon Road but of course would admit of a good pack trail being made. From the general appearance of the country, the main ridges, principal canyons & the great variety of Rocky formations peculiar to a gold country, we are decided[ly] of the opinion that gold must exist in many places as well as veins of gold and silver bearing quartz rock. Having a common interest with other citizens of the Umpqua Valley I would earnestly recommend the organization of a prospecting expedition to set out early in the summer of 1864 to more thoroughly prospect the region of country passed over having full confidence that the developments which might thus be made now [?]every way amply compensate those who might be disposed to assist in aiding and encouraging its general outfit. LLW

20
Enrollment of Douglas County
Very soon after my return from the mountains, the war of the Rebellion raging in its unabated furry [sic], the Board of Enrollment for Oregon were directed to have this State enrolled preparatory for a draft. And I was Commissioned to make the enrollment of Douglas County, and set out upon my labors and Continued the same until completed. It requiring about 70 days in all. to make a complete finish of it: While a great many men in this county are straight out Secessionists and violently opposed to the Govt in every form, and although many threats had been made to whip, shoot + kill the Enrolling Officer, yet no opposition was met with and when the Enrollment was completed I had more friends among that class than before
swirls, S S W scribbles -- image

Indian Department
Hon. J. W. P. Huntington an intimate friend of mine was appointed Superintendent of Indian Affairs for Oregon in 1862, and before I was through with the Enrollment he wrote to me offering me a temporary position as Clerk in his office which was located Salem the Capital of the State.
I proceeded to Salem and remained until February when hearing that the County Clerkship of Douglas County was soon to become vacant. I returned at once to Rosebury and applied to the County court for the appointment which was at once Conferred upon me and I at once entered upon the duties thereof
LLW

County Clerkship
I was appointed to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of the Clerk whose term would have expired on the first of July.  Hence the term for which I was appointed would terminate at that time.  I therefore concluded to become the candidate of the Union party at the coming Election if practicable and soon found that I only had a scattered opposition and when the Union Convention assembled.  I received on the first Ballot a majority of 5 or 6 of all the votes cast.  The remainder being divided among different candidates.  At the Election in June I was elected by a majority of 205 the highest majority ever given for any candidate in Douglas County.  The office was worth about $3000.00 per year coin?. and I labored earnestly to do my whole duty in that capacity and believe that I gave fair general satisfaction to all.  L.L. Williams

Military
In the year 1862 a Regiment of Cavalry had been raised in Oregon for the purpose of suppressing insurrection and to chastise hostile Indians. This Regt was stationed at different point along the frontier, the lake, the place recently occupied by the U.S troops which had been recalled and ordered East to the seat of War.
The term of Enlistment of this Regt was drawing to a close, and as there was no prospect for the war to close at present. The Govenor of Oregon was directed to raise an Infantry Regt to take the place of the Cavalry as soon as they should be mustered out of service, and among other appointments Stephen Rigdon of Lane County was appointed Recruiting Officer for the Counties of Lane and Douglas. Rigdon was Commission a Conditional 2nd Lieutenant to be entitled to that position upon the Company being raised   with the view of obtaining the Captaincy.
I had made up my mind to resign the County Clerks office and enlist as a soldier as soon as the Company was ready to be mustered into service.

The company was fully recruited and in February 1865 Rigdon and his prospective Lieutenants were summoned before a Board of examiners consisting of Capt J.M. Drake of the old Cavalry Regt, Capt Charles LaFollete of "A" Co. of the new Oregon Infantry Regt and Horace Carpenter.  Action U.S. Surgeon of the Infantry Regt and upon the examination Rigdon as well as his subordinates were rejected, which appeared like a hardship for he had lost several months time in raising the Company, had paid out several hundred dollars of his own private funds to meet contingent expenses and many of his own personal friends had enlisted under him who would not have enlisted at all had it not been expected that he was to command them.  
When A. C. Gibbs an old friend of mine whom I became acquainted with upon my arrival at Gardner in 1851 was elected Govenor [sic] in 1864 and having learned that I was intending to enlist as soon as the Company was mustered into service,  at once sent a dispatch to me by telegraph (which by the way had been completed a few months) that he had appointed J.D. Applegate

23
One Jackson Kyle was enlisted soon afterwards and the Company now consisted of 84 enlisted men. Immediately after muster in I recd orders to proceed on the following any to Fort Vancouver in Washington Territory the Head Quarters of this Dept. and at 5 oclock P.M. the men were in readiness, and marched into Salem and were quartered for the night in the Legislature hall, preparatory for an early start down the River on a steamer in the morning.
Saturday March 18 1865
The handsome little Steamer "Enterprise" having been engaged to move the Company below, was ready at an early hour and at 4 oclock in the morning all hands bag & baggage was on board and she was cast loose and steamed down the River, at at 11 oclock we landed on the upper end of the Oregon City Port? where we landed, & the men were marched below the falls an on which Steamer "Senator" and were soon under headway for Portland where, without landing we were transferred to the Steamer "Fannie Troup", and proceeded down the River about 13 miles to its entrance into the broad and

Capt of the company and offered me the first lieutenancy in the company and I proceeded at once to Salem the capitol of the state and the general rendevous sic of the troops. This was about the last of February 1865, and on the 14th March I was summoned before the same examining board, as Capt. Applegate having declined the appointment, was examined and accepted only one question being asked and that a mathematical problem in writing in which the following is a copy: 
"If a soldier is allowed 1/7 of a cord of wood per week with 1/3 added, N. of Lat. 42 (sign for degrees) N.What would 10 soldiers be entitled to in 11 3/4 days."
I thought I had had been accustomed to unknown for some time past, yet this was a stumper and it was some time before I succeeded in producing the correct result.
I was asked no further questions but was requested to be on hand to be mustered into service on the 17th when the company was duly mustered into unknown the service of the WS by Lieut. Wm. Capus, 1st lieut of the W.T. Infy who had been commissioned for that purpose. William Grant was mustered in as first, and David W. Applegate as second lieutenant.

24
Armies of the Union! The excitement manifested by the Capt and crew of the Steamer was caught up by the strong on shore and in a few minutes more Vancouver and the Garrison was one wild scene of excitement and enthusiasm. The Commander of the "Pacific Division" telegraphed at once to Genl Alvord to celebrate the event by a salute of 600 guns which were fired from the Batteries. All was joy at our national prospect. The war was considered virtually over for Lee and his army was known to be the mainspring of the Southern Confederacy. The soldiers were cheered with a prospect of an early discharge. The enthusiasm quickly subsided and two days afterwards at 11 oclock A.M. of April 15 1865 the telegraph brought us the hart rending intelligence of the assassination of President Lincoln and Secretary Seward which foul deed had been perpetrated last night in Washington City.
The sad news fell like a thunderbolt upon the town of Vancouver and the Garrison flags were placed at half mast and General Gloom everywhere prevailed. At 3 oclock P.M.

and expansive Columbia & turned up stream at about the middle of the P.M. we then landed on the Government Wharf at Fort Vancouver on the Washington Territory side where we were at once assigned to quarters, and after a few days order was brought out of Confusion and chaos and we were fairly embarked upon a military life in Garrison with the numerous and interesting incidents pertaining to the affairs of a port recognized as the General Head Quarters of the Department.
Nothing very unusual transpired until the 13 April when the Steamer "Fannie Troup" was seen coming up the Columbia, almost completely hidden by flag flying from ever spar & rope. the crew cheering as they approached attracting the attention of the City and Garrison, all anxious to know the cause, and upon the Boat arriving at the wharf it was announced that General Grant had acchieved a magnifficent victory over the Rebel army in Virginia and that the Rebel General Lee had surrendered with his whole army to the

a second dispatch was received stating that the President lived until 22 minutes past 7 oclock in the morning, and and having been unconscious from the time of being shot in the evening before.
This dispatch Seward was not dead, but was probably in a dieing condition.
Lincoln was shot in the back part of the head with a pistol while at the theatre while at about the same moment Seward was attacked while in bed and nearly killed by the knife of an assassin.
Sunday April 16 1865
Recd some further particulars of the assassination and the dispatches indicate that Seward is living and probably may recover.
Monday April 17 1865
In pursuance of Army Regulations, the Comdg officer of the Post and Dept has ordered guns to be fired every half hour among the day from Sunrise until Sundown, having recd an official dispatch conforming the Presidents death.
I was officer of the day

25
and if this became my duty to superintend the firing. Sergt Mathers of H. Co to which I had command of being the Sergt in charge. A melancholy duty indeed for me yet could not avoid it.
Tuesday April 18 1865
Gloomy appearance generally wherever you go. Union men all sad and in mourning and Copperheads or those who are secessionists and in favor of the Rebellion are out of sight and not seen upon the streets - evidently secretly rejoicing over the Sad event which has cast a gloom over the whole civilized world
Wednesday April 19 1865
A Dispatch to the Comdg officer directs that 21 minute guns be fired at noon today. Which was accordingly done, and everything soon resumed its usual course.
On May 3rd I recd orders from H Qrs to be ready for a march with my company to Camp Watson in the Indian Country where I would report to Capt H. S. Small of G. Co Opr Car we proceeded up the Columbia River by steamer as far as the Cascades, where the

Portage of about 5 miles by a Rail Road on the North? South? bank was made, and from the head of the unclear we went on Board of the Steamer "Oneanta" and in the evening a little before night we had made the passage through through the Cascade Mts and was landed at Dallas City, and marched up to the Garrison back of the town about one mile and for choice we went into Quarters on the creek a short distance West of the Fort, where for the want of the necessary transportation we were obliged to remain until
Thursday May 11 1865
When our transportation train of 5 wagons, each drawn by 6 mules were in readiness, and were soon packed up and on our way passing through the City and up the Columbia River for a distance of about 4 miles, then leaving the River to our left we bear off to the right into the open hilly country and camped for the night on a small tributary of the Columbia called 5 Mile Creek. A small growth of willows along the branch is the only timber of any kind to be found. While the hills are

Friday May 12 1865
Travelling about 8 miles over a hilly country, we descend a very steep mountain, by a very good wagon Road grade to the deep Canyon of the Des Chutes River a rapid & rocky stream. With bluffs 5 or 600 feet high. The River at this place is about 50 yds wide, and apparently contains a smaller volume of water than is found in the same stream one hundred miles farther up. We ascended the Bluffs on the opposite side by a Ravine which led us up to the top by a crooked route through a deep gorge gradually ascending for about 2 miles and at this point without wood or fuel of any kind we were obliged to camp.
Saturday May 13 1865
Our General course today is S.E over a high and dry, grassy plain, gently rolling with no timber or water, and after travelling 13 miles we camped in a Ravine where a small spring afforded us a limited supply of very poor water

Thursday M 18 1865
Following down Current Creek about 3 miles and then strike off to the right over a hilly & grassy country and after a march of 13 miles we came upon "John Days" River and camped. Here we were met by Lieut Wm M. Hand from Camp Watson with a Detachment of Cavalry, and we all camped together.
This morning in pursuance of Instructions, I detailed Lieut Grant and 20 men as an escort to Hon D.P. Thompsons surveying Expedition, who is instructed to

to connect with the Govt survey near where we camped last night and run a Meridian South to a point at or near the South Boundary of the State. The expedition was rationed for 50 days and for transportation we had procured a small pack train from the H.H.L.M. at Ft. Dallas.
Friday May 19 1865
Follow up John Days River about 1/2 mile, the Road bears off to the right over the hills and soon descend into the little valley of "Bridge" Creek. And following up stream some distance we camped at a point near "Penningtons Ranch"
Saturday May 20 1865
About 7 miles over a high & rough hilly Country and we descend in to the valley of "Little Cottonwood" a tributary of Bridge Creek, and ascend the mountain by a Ravine to the summit of about one mile on the opposite side and went into camp, Grass and water good - and small wood plenty

Timber aplenty on the tops of the mountains around and near us. Several of the men who were not used up by walking asked permissions to go out in search of game. Asserting their opinion that deer, elk, antelope and mountain sheep inhabited the surrounding heights, of course, permission was given and also went out myself but soon after returned and found that the men had procured a vase amount of meat which all hands pronounced splendid elk meat which had been killed by the hunters up in the mountain back of camp: the meat was certainly splendid, but some doubt exists as to whether it was elk or beef as ranches were on Little Cottonwood which were occupied by whites who were engaged in the lucrative business of cattle raising. 
Sunday May 21, 1865
About 5 miles from our camp by a gently rolling wood. We passed Rock Creek tributary of John Day, and in about 5 miles of another by a good road we arrived at Camp Watson the place of our destination where

Monday May 22d 1865
Today we rested ourselves in Camp, doctored our feet and mended our breeches; 

   Camp Watson is a pleasantly located place, situated at the junction of the small & living branches of cold water in the margin of a thick pine forest on the South & a ridge of grass land about two hundred yards to the North while E & W the ground was level and with quite heavy pine timber

Tuesday May 23d 1865
Recd orders from Capt Small to Send Lieut Applegate and 10 men back on the Road and establish a Camp on Bridge Creek and remain there for the present. and to patrol the Road and keep the Country well scouted in that vicinity

   We set out at 9 A.M. in a South Course upon an old

I at once reported myself to Cap Small of the Cavalry who had for some time been stationed here with his Company to protect the travel and settlers on and along the Canyon City Road as the Road we had travelled from the Dalles is More Generally known, Canyon City being a mining town about 50 miles further to the Eastward on and near the head waters of John Days River

    Camp Watson was named after Lieut Stephen Watson who was killed by the Snake Indians, in an engagement near Crooked river about 25 miles south of here on the 18th day of May 1864
   The most of the men were unaccustomed to walking and of course had become very tender footed in travelling over the hard road generally dusty & hot.  A quite a number of them were entirely unable to travel and all were glad to reach our destination where we could expect rest and recruit a little.  My own feet were blistered in many places and my efforts

wagon Road made by the military in 1864, and after travelling about 15 miles in a South Course through a quite rough & heavy timbered country, we all encamped at a small flat called Summit prarie:  From Camp Watson we immediately begin the ascent of the Mountains which divide the waters of John Days River from the Crooked River which is a tributary of the Deschutes emptying into that River in the East side at a point a little north of the Fremont Crossing near the "Three Sisters"

A course about S.S.W. over a bleak and desolate, barren looking region for about 10 miles brought us to crooked River a stream about 30 feet wide running West, with high rocky cliffs below and quite extensive bottoms or flats of Sand and Sage brush above

Tuesday May 30 1865
Making about 3 miles North and we find ourselves upon the high rock Bluffs on the south side of a wide & quite extensive vally many hundred feet below us, and through which Beaver Creek and its tributaries flow

7 miles we came upon the south fork of John Day River about 5 miles below the mouth of the S.F. of S.F. 
At this point we intersect the Canyon City Road at about 18 miles from Camp Watson a small detachment of cavalry having been stationed here for some time, was now relieved and went on to Camp Watson while I was instructed to remain here until June 6th. 
This recently has been the scene of many Indian depredations during the last year and many persons have been murdered and much stock driven away. I kept little scouting parties out every day until Tuesday June 6 when in pursuance of orders I returned to Camp Watson over a hilly country for 18 miles where we arrived in the afternoon. 
This Scout has been rather a pleasure trip rather than otherwise. The infantry soldiers endured the trip well. They made the same marches as the cavalry.
The country generally rough and rocky. Some of the highest mountains covered with

but as a general thing scattering of sage brush and juniper was the principal timber. while alder, willow, birch, also aspen and cottonwood was found along all the streams. Beaver in abundance and a few antelope and occasionally a deer or a flock of sage hens were to be seen and a few trout may be found in all the streams. But all things considered it is a poor country for game. 
Indications of gold were to be found on nearly all the water courses but although the country traversed has been slightly prospected at different times, yet no deposits have been found that would justify working.
We remained at Camp Watson undergoing the usual routine of camp life until Wednesday June 14 1865 when I was directed by the company officer to take 20 men of the Infy and proceed on a Scout after Indians to the North Fork [crossed out:  or Middle Fork as it is sometimes called] of John Days River.
It was raining this morning but we set out tolerable early. No tents or shelter of

35
any kind being furnished. our course was Northward through a treeless region of country.  grassy on hilly. for 15 miles when coming to the margin of a narrow belt of pine timber along a ravine where we camped for the night ;  Deer tracks appeared quite plenty in this vicinity and myself and others while hunting in the evening saw several. several shots were fired but George Ligdon the only one of the hunting party who never killed a deer. was the only one who succeeded in securing venison.  He killed a very nice one which was brought in and enjoyed by the soldiers in camp
Thursday June 15 1865
It rained considerable during the night. and as has been the case before the men made temporary shelters out of their blankets, pitching them in the form of a tent

of the distance we followed an old and well beaten Indian trail over very rough round until we reached the [?] bottom or flat bordering the River. Friday June 16 1865

  John Days River at this point is about 75 yds wide swift and rapid. and too deep to be forded anywhere.
   We found two or three small drift logs and with the aid of ropes we succeeded in making a kind of raft with a view of crossing over to the opposite side and by 8 oclock A.M. We were ready to embark   Two men were set across for sentinels upon the opposite side. then pack saddles [?apparahoes?] camp Equippage &c & then afterwards the men  in small attachments of 2 or 3 were set over.  after which our pack mules were driven into the River and swam over also

The River rose several feet in a short space of time, streams of water pouring off from the Mountains into the Canyons and ravines on every side:  The storm subsiding we made our way to Camp and found that about half the detachment was still out, but very soon after all hands returned as wet as it was possible for men to be none of them finding any shelter except from the scattering pines growing over the Mountain sides, and those who had remained in camp had fared no better

    Game is no where very abundant. deer are occasionally found and Elk and mountain sheep are occasionally seen:  Much of the elevated table lands is covered with broken rock.  The Canyons or gorges through which the streams pass are generally chasms cut out many hundred feet deep, the bluffs steep with "rim rock" as it is sometimes called at the top or in other words perpendicular walls of Basalt at the tops of the Bluffs facing the streams.  The streams are rapid and cold, the praries covered with flowers, and during the early summer is one of the delightful regions of the Pacific slope

Dr. Walker with train and escort accompanied by Lieut Grant, Carrying our return mail left this Morning for Camp Watson leaving us rationed to the 10 but no transportation and the season so far advanced that every days delay seriously delayed the expedition, for our orders were to erect winter quarters on Silves [sic] River. cut or contract for a sufficient quantity of hay for our public animals during the winter. it was therefore with much regret that I was obliged to send the small train back as ordered

   From our camp on the head of Beaver Creek, we ascend the mountains by a gradual ascent S.S.E and from the summit  we found the timber open and comparatively level for about 8 miles when we suddenly found ourselves upon a high rock point of the Mts with a deep canyon on each side uniting immediately before us .  We at once descended to the junction below and found a

command.  The letter had been opened and the order had been delayed on the way.  From appearances it had reached Camp Watson on the day we left there

  In addition to "H" Co which I commanded. 2d Lieut John Bowen 1st Ogn Cav was to join the Command from his station on Willow Creek. with 30 Cavalry and 15  Infantry mostly of "F" Compay [sic]
  Capt Small was to turn over to me all transportation that could be spared from Camp Watson and Lieut Bowen was to bring with him all that could be spared from Camp Colfax on Willow Creek
   I immediately issued orders for the organization of the Silvies River Expedition, assuming Command, appointing 1st Lieut Wm Grant A.A.Q.M. and A.C.S of the expedition, and directed him to proceed at once to Camp Watson and further if necessary to obtain the necessary transportation supplies and medical stores &c for the expedition, Lieut Bowen was ordered to join me on Silves [sic] River. Lt Applegate was ordered to join me from Camp Watson at once

brisk little mountain stream of about 6 feet wide flowing S.E undoubtedly a tributary of Silvies River which heads in this vicinity and flows South to the Harney Lake basin:  we followed down about a mile and we leave the timbered Country, and scattering juniper & sagebrush abounds with narrow bottoms along the Creek filled with Beaver dams.  The stream about 20 feet wide the mountains each side high & rocky:  The Silvies River rises in three Mts, and runs about 60 miles in a South Course and empties into the Eastern part of Harney Lake.

  Found some Indian sign but nothing new in that line 
  It was nearly night.  We had no blankets, nights cold and a fire indispensible, so we left the creek for a favorable camp ground which we found a short distance to the Westward in a clump of pines in the bottom a deep canyon

Sunday Sept 3d 1865
With a pocket Cumpass [sic] we laid our course for Camp where we arrived a little

54
before night having travelled about 50 miles. saw some deer today and several shots were fired but no Meat was obtained
Monday Sept 4 1865
Sent a detachment down the Creek today but they returned in the afternoon having found more Sage hens than Indians 
Tuesday Sept 5 1865
With 9 men I went out East from camp & ascended a high rocky mountain. from the summit of which we could see the Three Sisters in the Cascade Mts as their white head tops loomed up about 100 miles due West of us:  Mt Jefferson was also visible bearing N. 70º W
Although this is a poor game country. yet deer, antelope & Mountain sheep are occasionally found. (deer being the Most common) while Sage hens. prarie chickens Jackass Rabbits. large gray wolves and Cayotes are found almost every day.  Beaver are plenty in all the streams. while trout Can be caught in considerable quantities.  We killed 2 deer on our return
Wednesday Sept 6 1865
With 10 men I set out North Easterly

55
the more extensive Beaver Creek Vally leaving the Canyons behind and again intersecting the Yreka & Canyon City Wagon trail, finding 2 fresh beef tracks going north we followed At a rapid rate. and in Perlina Vally the animals were found & two or three Well directed shots brought them down.  Camp was soon made in the willows along the creek and large quantities of nice beef was roasted and eaten that night
Friday Sept 8 1865
We returned to Camp today by a different route find no indications of Indians. except the Cattle. which had probably escaped from them in some place while being hurriedly driven off.

  Sage hens are very numerous in large flocks and very tame and not not [sic] much inferior to turkey.  days pleas [sic] and warm and nights Cold and frosty, ice freezing an half inch or more in thickness in camp kettles each night

Saturday Sept 9 1865
Ice about an inch thick this morning, being somewhat the coldest yet experienced this fall

  In the afternoon Capt Small came

over a low range of broken Bald hills, reaching the summit. in about 6 miles. thence descending through a thinly timbered slope some three or four miles to a tributary of Beaver Creek, where we had the Good fortune to find 3 head of Beef Cattle which had probably strayed from some Band. that had been driven off by the Indians

   They were very wild. in good condition and for a wonder had until this time been spared to run at large in the heart of the Indian Country to fall into the hands of Uncle Sams soldiers. who are always hungry and ready to convert everything of that kind to their own use
   We returned to camp driving one of the Beeves which we had crippled  to camp where he was kept in reserve for a day or two then killed

Thursday Sept 7 1865
With 13 men I set out down Beaver creek in search of Indians or other game.  at 13 miles passed Camp Drake. Where Capt Drake was encamped with a detachment of Cavalry in 1864, and at 5 miles further we entered

56
them and after travelling about 10 miles through the heavy timber we fell upon a small canyon through which water was flowing South. supposed to be a tributary of Silvie Creek upon which Indian Springs were situated.  We followed down this Stream about 6 miles, travelling being fair & camped in a little grassy bottom of ten of 12 acres of good grass
At the junction with a small stream coming in from the West. which two streams form a brisk little creek of about 15 feet wide

  It rained nearly all day, and was cold in the afternoon & scattering snow flakes were occasionally seen intermixed with the rain. but wood was plenty and all hands were soon in comfortable quarters for the night or at least as comfortable as we could well be without shelter.  Brush houses & blanket tents was resorted to by a few of the men, but a good fire in the open air exposed to a heavy storm is generally pretty good for campers in this country where they are often bothered to obtain fuell [sic]

Monday Sept 11 1865
I [sic] rained but little during the night and we were under way at an early

in from Camp Watson. bringing further supplies, and with the intention of moving us to Indian Springs a point on Silvie Creek about 30 Miles in a course about S.S.W

  Five Beeves were driven in for a part of our subsistence.  I had expected my 2d Lieut D. W. Applegate to join me at or before this time, but Capt Small informed me that he had sent him from Camp Watson on Aug 30 on a scout to vicinity of Canyon City with orders for him to join the Command at Indian Springs

Sunday Sept 10 1865
A rainy morning, and appearances indicate a wet rainy day.  Not having sufficient transportation to move our Supplies. Camp and Garrison Equippage at one trip. I concluded to load the train and start out with 15 of my command leaving the remainder of the freight & men at this camp until the train could return

  We set out southerly Capt Small and his detachment of Cavalry in advance driving the Beef Cattle with

hour in the morning. the Stream appeared to turn to the Eastward through a Canyon and we turned more to the right and at about 4 miles the pine timber became more scattered & soon thereafter we left the pine land altogether, and entered upon high barren Rocky hills much cut up with canyons & deep rocky ravines. and after travelling about 10 miles farther we descended from the rocky table lands to the vally of Silver creek where we at once found ourselves at Indian Springs our present destination:

   At this point Silver Creek emerges from the region of rocky hills and canyons, to a wide sage plain of two or more miles in width. and on the margin of this flat about 200 yds west of where Silver Creek enters the plain. Indian Springs burst out from the immediate foot of the Mts forming a stream of 8 or ten feet wide running a mile or two South through the Sage parralel [sic] to the Main Stream where it turns to the left and sinks on the plain

   Silver Creek is about 30 feet wide at this point and runs off through the plain a S.E course to Harney Lake, but at its present low stage of water sinks in the porous vally a few miles below
   Willow timber of considerable size grows along the Creek and pine timber appears on a high Mountain N.E. and about 5 or 6 miles away
   Capt L. S. Scott of the 4 Cal Inf has been directed to this pint to establish a camp and is supposed to be provided with supplies to last 300 men until April 1, 1866. and that the Silvers River Epedition [sic] was to make requisition upon this Camp for all supplies needed until that time
   As we do not know at what time the Capt left Ft Dalles, we cannot tell just when he may be expected at this place.
   The day has been cold and blustering. rain. snow. and heavy wind combined to make it very disagreeable indeed.
   We were soon comfortably encamped in the sage brush and the willows along the stream and a few Juniper trees a short distance back on the side hill furnished an abundance of fuell [sic] ;

58
chickens are plenty along the streams and the white and blue cranes shitepoke were often startled from their favorite retreat along the Stream 
Wednesday Sept 13 1865
Day fine.  fishing and hunting was all that could be done to relieve the monotony of camp life
Thursday Sept 14th 1865
Wind heavy and cold from the North and blowed furiously all night.  At about ten or eleven oclock I was somewhat surprised to see Lieut Bowen and two or three of his men coming in from down the creek;  He had been ordered by Capt Small to join me at Harney Lake which was contrary to the orders I had sent him which orders he had not received

   The Lieut had 30 Cav and 15 Infy and had crossed the Country from Willow Creek to Harney Lake and from thence up Silver creek and had camped his men on the creek a short distance below
  He reported to me for duty. and a report of his trip in writing was made out and soon submitted by which it appeared he had met with Indians on Malheur River but was unable to bring them to a fight

Friday Sept 12th 1865
This morning was bright & clear and the ground & bushes white with frost!  Capt Small with his Cavalry and Pack train returned to our former Camp on Beaver Creek, and will forward the train with the remainder of our men & supplies to this Camp at once.

  At about 9 oclock A.M. Lieut Applegate with his detacht of Infy came in from Canyon City.  he had made a quick trip but reported no Indian Sign:  My orders had been strict to forward his pack animals to Camp Watson immediately upon his arrival.  I therefore started it out without delay
   After sending out small scouting parties up & down the Creek and ascertaining that there were no Indians in the immediate vicinity. permission was given to the men to go and fish in the creek, but at all times to go armed and be ready for an emergency that might at any time present itself
   Quite an abundance of trout were caught some of which would weigh as much as 3 pounds, a few antelope inhabit the vally   Sage hens and prarie

59
Friday Sept 15 1865
Lieut Bowen moved up his detacht today. and before he reached our Camp one of those sad affairs took place which is almost the certain result which follows the taking of prisoners from the hostile tribes.

  The circumstances are rare, which justify the taking of prisoners while at war with hostile digger Indians and whenever circumstances do occur which justify a deviation from the General rule, the greatest care & Caution should at all times be observed to prevent a bad result therefrom:
  In the case of the prisoner captured by Lieut Bowen, a Sergt. a Corpl and two privates were detailed to take charge of the Indian and to guard him &c. and to march him to our camp and deliver him up to me.
  When they had reached a point about ½ mile from our camp the sudden report of firearms was heard and a commotion was seen among the men; With 5 or 6 men I proceeded at a rapid rate to the scene of excitement and saw the Indian lying dead upon the ground and a private of the Cavalry by the name of Andrew C. Barlow lying near him with a frightful gunshot wound in the head, he was

On Silvies River in Harney Lake Valley he had suddenly Came upon a band of 15 or 20 who were encamped upon the Stream. the Indians fled in every direction and as they had quite a large number of horses and mules with them they did not succeed in saving all. but the Lieut & his men succeeded in capturing 9 head of horses & 4 head of mules:  A high rocky point of a mountain about 4 miles distant was the only safe place of retreat for the Indians, and allthough many of them were on foot. and the entire distance level and smooth yet all succeeded in reaching the Mountain and making their escape in the rocks & cliffs at its top. except one old Indian who had concluded to take his chances by hiding under a sage bush and as he happened to be right in the direct route of the Cavalry he was discovered and taken prisoner
   At the first [?] quite a number of shots were exchanged and one Indian killed and a horse or two wounded
   I directed the Lieut to remain at his camp below until tomorrow at which time he would move up and join at the General Camp

60

  Barton was examined. and of course we could not easily determine whether his wound was or was not mortal, but we made a temporary stretcher out of a blanket and with the aid of 4 men, one at each corner the poor fellow was packed to my camp bleeding profusely from the wound and also from his lef [sic] ear and mouth and although suffering much, his wound was soon carefully dressed by myself and two men detailed to take Care of him:  He soon became sensible and talked quite freely but was suffering terrible agony but was made as comfortable as a man could be with a carbine bullet in his head:  The side of the skull is no doubt fracture somewhat, yet from his clear state of mind, do not consider that the wound is necessarily mortal
   Our best "wick-a-up" was prepared and a comfortable bed of of [sic] grass & blankets was made for the poor unfortunate. and here he must lie and suffer until Capt Scott arrives with a Surgeon in his command
   It was no doubt the intention of the Indian to overcome the guard and if possible make his escape in the thick sage brush on the plain
  The men were far more unguarded

still living but wholly unconscious

   The history of the affair as reported by the Sergt in charge and corroborated by the men was about as follows
   That private Andrew C. Barlow was walking about 3 steps in advance of the Indian, that Corpl [? Ha...?] was about the same distance behind. that the remainder of the little detacht were occupying their several positions about the same distance from the Indian forming a complete circle around him
   That all were jogging along merrily when suddenly the Indian whirled around and seized the Carbine from Corpl [?Ha...?] & as suddenly whirled and shot poor Barlow in the back part of the head. the ball striking about 2 inches back of the left ear and lodging in the bone somewhere near the left eye
   The movement was so quickly executed that the men had not time to interpose before Barlow was shot But as Barlow fell they charged upon the Indian and he was killed at once. a half dozen Bullets being put through him & several bayonets was also driven through his inanimate body

61
rations and 23 resolute men and accompany him to Silvies River and establish a temporary Camp, and explore the Country what little we was able to and await his return:  Our course was down Silver Creek about 12 miles in a S.E course where we encamped. there being no water except stinking stagnant water in filthy pools. and is only adapted for use when no better can be obtained. the level sage land and bottom bordering the creek at this Camp is about 1½ miles wide.  Good grass abounds and the tall rye grass gives the bottoms the appearance of a field of grain, except the grass is to be found only in bunches

   A short distance below our camp the mountain close in and forms a canyon into which the Stream (or its dry channel) passes on its way to Harney Lake below

Sunday Sept 17 1865
An early start this morning leaving the creek and striking across the bottoms in an E. course, we soon entered the sage hills covered with broken lava, with scattering Juniper trees;  In about 10 miles we passed over a low summit and descended a ravine to the

than soldiers should been. or the Indian would not been able thus easily to have obtained a carbine from one of their number

  It appears singular and very strange to me that a Carbine bullet striking as that bullet did, and at so short a distance did not penetrate the Skull and kill the man at once. by which act he would been indebted to the mistaken policy of extending too much leniency to a barbarous digger Indian
  To day the remainder of my men came in from Beaver Creek

Saturday Sept 16 1865
The condition of Barlow is unchanged, he is suffering much pain and complains of a great deal of soreness in his head. slept a portion of the night, and can talk quite freely this morning

  We only have supplies for a few days. and being entirely in the dark as to the future I deemed it the best course to pursue to send Lieut Bowen back to Willow creek and pack from there the supplies he had on hand at that camp, and as our destination was Silvies River in Harney Lake Vally I concluded to take 15 days
