  Silvies River takes its rise in the Canyon City Mts immediately back of that city and its General Course is about due South and loses itself in the marshes and swamps around the Eastern arm of Harney Lake

Monday Sept 18  1865
Lieut Bowen was [sic] his Cavalry force set out for Willow Creek this morning with instructions to return with all possible dispatch for I was certain of no transportation except the few animals he had with him and upon which I must wholly depend, in moving my men from Indian Springs provided no further transportation was furnished

   As the cavalry moved away I was left with 23 men in the heart of the hostile Indian Country and where it is generally supposed that large bands can easily be congregated together upon any sudden occasion that might require it
   As it was likely that we were to remain here shut up in this valley for at least two weeks as I was determined to scout as much as it was practicable for me to do without the aid of transportation

Eastward which we soon found to widen out with a pretty, but narrow vally, and soon came upon a brisk little stream which flows from a large spring to our left next to the foot hills, but sink very soon after reaching the level:  This little vally led us out into the main Silvies River Valley of low grass and Sage land; apparently about 20 miles wide E&W. & even wider N&S.

  As we entered the valley the thick willows along Silvies River were visible before us about 4 miles off due East.  We passed over the plain much of it covered with good grass and a large part of it being low appears to be covered with water during the winter & spring and now dry is covered with a white incrustation of alkali about an inch deep:  This alkaline substance is left from the evaporation of the water and is a pure & perfect salratus and is often used as such in the plains.  These dry ponds exist every where throughout this part of the valley, and large dry sloughs filled with a heavy growth of Tules, are also

63
Seen by by [sic] me upon other occasions   It appeared to burn up quickly with a column of black looking smoke, and soon died out.  We examined the plain around & about the place where the smoke had been seen, but could make no discoveries.   It was believed that Indians were concealed in the high tules which appeared in a Slough very near the place where the smoke had first appeared - 

   With 10 men I started out in that direction, and found instead of smoke, that the deception was caused by a whirl wind carrying up the black dust and ashes from the Ground which had been burned off some time previously
  We had been in Camp but a few minutes. when the Sentinel reported a dust on the West side of the vally about 5 miles away and a moving object.  with the aid of the glass I could distinctly make out 2 horsemen. coming nearly towards us and believing them to be Indians. I again took 10 men and started out in that direction with a view of waylaying them in the high grass and Tules, and I succeeded admirably in placing my

and as scouting would of necessity divide my little party. I set to work in the Morning to fortify our Camp.  a piece of level grass land was laid off about 25 yards square. a wall of sod put up about 2½ feet high. with a ditch inside about 2½ feet deep. inside of which I imagined that half of my men might defend themselves against any number of Indians which might be brought to bear against it. for situated as it was on the river bank in an open level plain. it was impossible for the men to be surprised or the Indians to approach unobserved:  The men worked faithfully and long before night the fortification was completed and really appeared to a much safer [?instution?] than I had at first anticipated:  an observatory of about 10 feet high was also built of sod and from its top with a glass the vally could be examined for a distance of at least 3 or 4 miles in any direction

   At about 3 oclock P.M the Sentinel reported a signal smoke about 2 miles off which showed. very plan & looked very much like a genuine signal smoke, often

64
another [?] of the River was where Lieut Bowen had had his little fight and Captured the Indian horses and mules a few days ago.  At a point about 6 miles above Camp we came to one of those peculiarities seldom witnessed of a River in its downward course seperating [sic] and running off in two different channels; 

  Silvies River at this point divides itself into two seperate streams, each about 40 feet wide, and run off through the plain for about 15 miles paralel [sic] to each other, from two to 6 miles apart and both then lose themselves in the marshes and Tule Swamps Around the Eastern arm of Harney Lake, which to distinguish it from the latter is sometimes called Malheur Lake:
   We followed up the River to a point where it emerges from the rough hills unto the plains and finding a favorable point we crossed over to the East side where we found several ranches recently deserted. and also many Indian tracks that had apparently been made this morning:  these tracks were of footmen and all appeared to

Men unobserved in a position which almost insured the death of the Indians unless they should materially change their course, On they came and at last we had the mortification in one sense allthough [sic] a pleasure in another of Meeting soldiers instead of Indians. for it proved to be Corpl Kelsay and private McCracken of my Company who had been sent from Indian Springs by Lieut Applegate to inform me that Capt Scott with his trains had arrived at that point and could transport the remainder of my Company to Silvies River which was gratifying intelligence to me
Tuesday Sept 19 1865
I sent the express back and directed Lieut Applegate to move to this camp at once. While I took 12 men and went up the River on a scout after Indians and to explore the vally & see what discoveries were to be made

  Fresh Indian sign was every where visible. and about 2 miles from this point on

65
direction: At a point near the River we had stopped to rest on a little smooth grass [?] and the men as is usually the case under such circumstances laid their rifles down upon the ground, and as we got up to start on. private Hazleton siezed [sic] the barrel of his gun & as he raised it up. the hammer caught somehow in the fine grass sufficient to discharge it. the men were just on their feet, grouped together preparatory for a start. and the gun was fired directly towards the center of the Group.  Corpl Johnsons gun stock was shattered, by the bullet and my left hand was powder burnt and also the faces of Private Smith & McPherson and all hands were frightened for fear some one was seriously injured.  No one was hit by the bullet. allthough [sic] it must have passed within a few inches of several of us.

  It was an act of inexcusable carelessness to thus endanger the lives of others. Yet but few men are found who are not equally as careless. hence the numerous accidents so common in this Country Consequent upon the Careless use of fire arms
  We proceeded up the River a few miles further and then returned back to the Vally or near to it. and camped in a thicket of

Strike off to the Eastward along the margin of the plain. and near the hills to our left. and as this was the route we had already laid out. we were somewhat hopeful we we [sic] might jump them up from some hiding place near by. as it was evident that they were not far away

   We could not follow their tracks far. but struck out on the course they appeared to have taken. and after travelling about 6 miles from the River. seeing many antelope & Rabbits, but no Indians, we encamped at the mouth of a little stream of water coming down out of the hills but which lost itself as soon as it reached the level sage plain below.
  Considerable game had been seen today. yet no shots had been fired.

Wednesday Sept 20 1865
In the absence of transportation it became necessary for us to return. an [sic] we soon reached Silves [sic] River. and followed up stream above the Vally about 4 miles to see what we might discover in that

66
Mountains. with volcanic rock and sage brush everywhere, and as we had obtained no knowledge of these highlands, I set out today with a half dozen men to ascend to their tops and scout along a few miles to the southward. in search of Indian ranches in and among the rocks and numerous ravines which usually furnish favorite lurking places for Indians to retreat to when pursued. and this also being the vicinity where the Indians had fled to the Rocks in the hills when attacked and pursued by Lieut Bowen a few days ago - on Sept 11 -
Saturday Sept 23d 1865

  Having been unable up to this time to Come upon the Indians. notwithstanding our active efforts, and the men becoming impatient to meet them in some form or other. I therefore proposed a scout down the River a few miles in search of Indians and to examine the valley for meadow land where hay could be cut for our animals during the winter
  In these little scouting expeditions my custom had been to take about half my men each day alternately. to favor them as much as possible and to enable them to perform strict guard duty.  I

Willows on the West or right bank having seen many Antelope, Sage hens - prarie chickens. rabbits and Blue & White cranes, but no firing had been done at Game.
Thursday Sept 21 1865
The last of our rations had been disposed of last night. We started down this morning on the East or left side of the River to the point where the same divides itself and runs off in two channels, thence down the more eastern branch about 6 miles to a point nearly due East of our Camp. finding several deserted Ranches and fisheries. and the day being some what advanced we rested a while, caught a fine mess of fish and then struck off across the plain between the two streams for our camp about 5 miles away where we arrived in due course of time.  having seen a great deal of Indian sign but no Indians
Friday Sept 22 1865
About 2 1/2 miles S.W. from camp rises quite abruptly from the plain a [?ser.......?] of rough and rocky table

69
and not over 150 yds wide (from Silvies River vally to Harney Lake Vally) for a distance of about three miles back where it connects with the main Mountains.

  Upon this point we had a splendid and extensive view of the vally.   as far up Silvies River as the Mountains above our camp. and to the S.E. as far as Malheur Lake. the eastern arm of Harney Lake about 12 miles distant. and S.W. to Harney Lake about 15 miles distant. all the intervening space being an extensive level sandy sage plain. except the very narrow strip of grassland bordering Silvies River. which soon appeared to expand into open Meadow lands about 5 miles further downstream towards Malheur Lake: The thick growth of Willows immediately bordering the River. generally about 25 yds in width could be traced by the winding sinuousities of the River from where it entered the valley about 15 miles above to a point about 3 miles below where the willow timber appeared to terminate and the River to enter upon level meadows
  Upon this Mountain point we discovered two moccasin tracks one somewhat larger than the other which had been made this morning. and apparently not many minutes before we were

therefore set out with 12 men. each with 40 rounds of cartridges & following down stream upon the right bank of the River. examining the willows carefully for Concealed Ranches, for about 7 miles in a Course about S.E., to a rocky point of the Mountain on the right reaching to within two or 300 yds of the River. and at this place the level Sage Vally appeared to turn off nearly west toward Harney Lake

 To this rocky point of the Mountain the Indians fled for safety when their camp was surprised by Lieut Bowen on the 11th inst in the Eastern prong of Silvies River about 3 miles East of here
   This mountain raises abruptly about 400 feet from the plain with perpendicular (or  rim rock) basaltic rock as you near the top, with huge masses of broken boulders. that have let loose from the main cliffs. and rolled down the hill. lodging along the steep sides all the way from the top to the bottom forming elegant fortifications. behind which retreating Indians could easily bid defience [sic] to a pursuing enemy
  The top of this ridge covered with small sage and broken lava. so flat & comparatively level

68
and [?Groves?] in bunches a few feet apart. the ground sanday [sic] and the day becoming warm:  We soon found ourselves gaining upon the Indians. and not long afterwards observed that one of them was a boy who appeared to be unable to make as fast progress as his larger companion  This was encouraging to the men  and a greater effort on our part was made:  The Indians probably noticing the fact that we were gaining up on them. and realizing that no assistance could be rendered them from the course they were going. that they could not possibly avoid us by striking up the Mountain. where no timber appeared. struck off from the foot of the Mountain at once into the plain. and steered for the large Tule swamp or channel connecting Malheur Lake on the East with Harney Lake on the West:  The distance across this plain to the said arm of Harney Lake appeared to be about 8 miles:  The Indians increased their speed, while we followed in an exciting chase for nearly the whole distance. realizing the fact that the Indians would obtain assistance from that direction or be able to enter the Tule swamp and make their escape. unless they could be overtaken before they

there. and in fact this was a splendid observatory and had apparently been much used by the Indians for look outs and for signal fires, for it commanded the most Complete and extensive view of the entire vally of any other point around it

  The Indian tracks. upon examination appeared to have gone down off the Mountain to the Sageplain below, or they had taken position in the rocks to avoid us;  The plain was carefully examined in every direction with a spy glass but no discoveries were made:  We descended from the point found their tracks in the sand and a few moments afterwards we discovered the two Indians, about a half mile off near the foot of the Mountain point:  The men were eager for a chase as this was the first sight we had had of a hostile Snake Indian. the Most dreaded all the Western tribes.
    We set out after them at a full run, or in a military sense at "Double Quick" without much if any hope of overtaking them unless some accident should interpose and place them within our reach;  The sage brush was about 4 feet high

We were within about 300 yds of them when this took place and we fired several shots at them but as far as we were able to judge, without effect

   Upon the opposite side of this swamp, the Mountains rose precipitously about 4 or 500 feet. & from what we had seen we were of the opinion that Indian Ranches might be situated along the Sloughs near the foot of these Mts from which the Indian horsemen had came.
   It was now 11 oclock AM. day hot and Men thirsty as well as tired, and Camp 16 miles off.
   We rested our selves for about an hour. and that hours delay came near proving fatal to our little scouting party
   As we were about ready to commence our march towards Camp. the men grumbling at their miserable luck as they called it, of the Indians escape

The Indians soon beating back a little to avoid our shots

   He before stated we were 16 miles from Camp. and in the thick sage brush, and no very desirable place to lie in.  after night should set in. and no prospect of bringing the Indians nearer to us. or getting nearer to them. We therefore move along slowly in the direction towards our camp, laying our course direct towards the long point of the Mountain about 8 miles off & near where we had first began our exciting chase after the two Indians this morning
   As we moved the 14 Indians also moved in the same direction without changing their relative position in regard to us.  We therefore had thus become the direct center of a moving circle a steady fire from the Indians directed at the hub. while ours was directed at the outer rim
    This was new business for the most of the men. and they seemed to enjoy it well. as long as the Indian Bullets fell short of us.
   We kept moving as steady as practicable, keeping the men in single file a  few steps apart, and thought that if they persisted in the pursuit that when we reached the

They were much more bold than the first 14 and [?] at a furious charge.  We reserved our fire. until such time as rendered it certain that it need not necessarily be wasted. and opened upon them with a full volley which somewhat disconcerted their plans, and scattered them promiscuously about on the plain. and they soon formed around us on every side taking positions with the first at about 300 yds distant & a continual fire was at once opened up & steadily kept up

    While thus situated. and in considerably danger. we were not much alarmed for to say the least we could move in any direction we wished to go. for as we moved the body of Indians moved with us without breaking the ring which encircled us
    Men were specially intrusted to guard a particular quarter, and notwithstanding the vigilance of the brave and watchful McPherson, a dismounted Indian would occasionally approach behind some high sage brush in the rear and fire a raking shot which would whistle uncomfortably close to our heads. or scatter the sage brush about us rendering our position very

reinforcement much more so than the horsemen, for being fleet of foot and unencumbered that could run round under the Sage brush. and were continually jumping up & firing at us from distances of not over 50, 75 or 100 yds. and usually dodged down in time to avoid our shots. and as they thus dodged down out sight would glide away into some other part of the brush and watch for another or more favorable opportunity, and out of the 30 or more footmen in the fight, it was often noticed that for two or three hundred yds that not over a half dozen of them would be in sight at one time and those with the aid of the horsemen kept up a brisk fire at us from each side with a view of checking our progress or more [?partientarly?] attracting our full attention. until the skulkers on foot could gain favorable positions to fire upon us

    As we neared the Mountain, and when within about a half mile from it, about 12 or 15 of the horsemen hastened forward climbed to the top and we had the mortification of seeing them dismount and

gloomy:  Much of our safety depended upon our own quick & active movements. and therefore had not allowed a halt upon any consideration since the fight began, except for the purpose of firing:  Therefore believing that our best course. and most favorable one considering the surrounding Complications was to diverge from the course We had been travelling, so suddenly turning to the right At something more than a right angle and travelling paralel to the Mountain Point on our left, we laid our course for a conspicuous bunch of Willows on Silvers River about 5 miles distant * which we have no doubt was a disappointment to those Indians who had intercepted us on the Mountain:

    A large number massed themselves along the foot of the Mountain running from rock to rock and keeping up a Continual string of fire from the numerous large boulders which had broken loose from the cliffs above and rolled down to the level sage plain
    Corpl William J. Johnson a young man of about 23 & a back woodsman from Lane County a good hunter and marksman who had been specially charged

   Silvers River was about 5 miles off. sandy ground and infernal sage brush about 4 feet high the entire distance. yet we moved on. not knowing just where we would be Compelled to go before the fight was over:  The men were place in single file 12 or 15 paces apart. and whenever ready a man or two at a time would step out of the ranks & fire his piece; and hurry forward to his place again. reloading as he passed along. these who  were specially detailed to guard the different sides were directed to watch that direction and no other
     The men were all fully awake to a sense of their danger were perfectly cool and the most of them good marksmen. were tired, thirsty and weary and could only walk at a moderate pace
     The Indians were suffering considerable from our rapid firing but the most of them who were

74
growth of Willows grew along the River. the Indians in front as they reached the River separated and entered the Willows above and below while we were terribly pressed from behind:  It was evident that no time must be lost. a short delay until the Indians could place themselves in proper position in the willows and in front would be almost certain destruction to us

    Our only safety appeared to be in crossing the River and gaining a position on the smooth & level plain beyond:  Private Alex Griffin of Co. "H" Ogn Infy had just been severely wounded in the left hip.  he had done well until that time. but the wound had completely unnerved him.  I had to scold and threaten him to prevent him from giving up entirely, and however painful it may appear it became necessary to intimidate him into obedience
   I had no rifle or other weapon but a navy size six shooter.  John L. Crow a young man had become so exhausted that he felt unable to pack his own gun, and I had for some time been using it. and was in the attitude of firing at an Indian a short distance off when Griffin was wounded

firing at us from a short distance, being afraid to expose their heads above the sage therefore generally fired so quick that their bullets passed over our heads.  A few of these fellows were killed, but generally they would dodge down in time to avoid our shots, for we could seldom see them until they fired, and then they were out of sight in a moment sounding the frightful war whoop as they would plunge in to the sage brush & disappear. to repeat the same thing over again the first favorable opportunity

    The men were held ready at all times to meet a charge, if it should be made, about one half of the men firing at a time, and the others being ready to fire about the time the first had loaded,   Three Revolvers were kept in readiness and the men at all times were urged to load with all possible dispatch after firing
   As we approached Silvers River I feared the men could not control themselves sufficient to guarantee a safe crossing, they were weary and exhausted, faint & thirsty. and the day hot and dusty.  My mouth was so badly parched I could scarcely give command.  A thick

75
moments pause.  to guard the front and to prevent the Indians from gaining the position they were evidently striving for in the Willows immediately in in front of us on the opposite side.  The other 6 were directed to take a hasty drink and relieve the others

  I waded the stream without halting, pushed through the willows on the opposite side. and watched the movements of the Indians in front as well as the men at the water and in about 20 seconds time, I gave the command for the men to fall in and instantly found every man at his post, and we rushed out of the Willows at as rapid a pace as we were able into the level plain about 250 yards where no brush or sage appeared and here we rested ourselves for the first time with a sentinel facing the four Cardinal points.  The Indians taking position on every side as usual but not nearer than 200 yds
    Our run from the River to this point was much quickened by the volleys of bullets fired from the thick willow timber along the river above and below. and it was a miraculous event that none of us were hit, their balls were whizzing past us and raising the dust at every step, and their marks upon the ground

It was thought that the shot had been fired at me. the bullet was heard whistling as it Came along it passed so close to me that I dodged to one side, and Griffin being at that moment very nearly in range, the ball struck him in the hip. hitting his hip bone and glancing off.  I heard the bullet strike & from the sound thought it had hit his cartridge box. but after firing my piece I looked round and Griffin had thrown down his gun had dropped off his Cartridge box, and commenced groaning at a fearful rate & threw himself under a sage bush.  A moment satisfied me that the wound was not a dangerous one, and not of such a nature to justify him in giving up or annoying or hindering the remainder of the detachment whose every possible effort was required to prevent all hands from being run over & cut to pieces
    Instantly upon striking the River which was a channel of about 4 feet deep cut through the level. three men were faced about to protect the rear and three others were ordered through the stream without a

76
dispair.   Johnson had been knocked down by a bullet grazing his temple and McPherson had his clothes cut in several places:  The loss of either of those men would been a loss to have been deplored. for in that event it is not unlikely that the detachment might have been cut off

   Our camp was 7 miles above & on the opposite side of the River.  We slowly moved on. every man was watchful and done his duty manfully.  It was nearly night. the most of the footmen were either in front, or along the River to our left between us and the Willows. the bulk of the horsemen being at our right and in the rear:  There was no cessation in the firing;
   Private Smith of "F" Co Ogn Infy was struck upon the leg with a bullet which for a moment seemed to parallyze him.  I feared he was seriously hurt as I saw him fall and settle down upon the ground. but the sensation was only momentary, and we were soon moving along:
   The character of the ground and the dwarf sage, was such that we believed we could march direct to camp. without incurring much risk. for the open plain enabled us to keep the Indians back so that the

were seen in places six months afterwards

    We considered ourselves now comparatively safe.  We were out of the region of the abominable sage brush & on an open grassy plain with stunted sage  of a slight growth alternating, and which would give the enemy no advantage
   A steady fire was kept up all the time from each side and the disagreeable whiz of the bullets could be heard at every moment
   After resting for a time we again moved on turning up the Vally N.W. in the direction of our Camp hoping that the firing of our guns or the whooping of the Indians might be soon heard and that we would receive that aid from camp which we so much needed.
   Corpl Johnson & private McPherson were my two best supporters and I felt indeed thankful that I had those two gallant young men with me upon this trying occasion.  They performed their arduous duty at all times most nobly, fearfully exposed and bravely facing dangers from which most any one would have shrunk with a heart of

77
favored all day, fortune still favored us and not a man was hit, their aim being so high that the bullets has passed over us.  The men were at once ordered into a little dry sink to our left and from this position we had five or six good shots at the Indians not over 40 or 50 yds distant several of whom were seen to fall & roll down into the little slough.

   During the high waters in the spring of the year, there are many channels of water running through this plain but during the summer become dry often forming a kind of dry canal. through which a man might pass in a half bent position, unperceived by a person who might happen to be near by, and at one side:   The slough from which these Indians had fired at us led up from the River on our left and they had reached this point unperceived by us and our first knowledge of the existence of the slough, was the volley fired therefrom.  The sink into which we had now taken refuge proved to be a kind of the same dry channel from which those concealed Indians had fired
    It was nearly dark and our Camp 3 miles off,  A blazing fire in our rear creeping along gradually towards us, and any amount

most of their Bullets fell short of us. and often as much as 50 yds short, while a few fired at a greater elevation passed over our heads

   At sundown we were within 4 miles of camp, the Indians whooping & yelling as furiously and the firing unabated on either side
   At this juncture a mounted Indian with a blazing torch in his hand. rode out of the Willows on the River above us, setting a line of fire for about 2 miles in length in a line angling across our route, the grass was dry & burned rapidly.  We felt certain that some trap was being set, but hardly knew what. but hurried along & passed between the open spaces in the fire line. when suddenly we were completely stunned by a platoon of about a dozen Rifles from a little dry slough in front & to the left about 50 yds distant.
   This was between sundown & dark, the flash & report of the guns & the whistling of the bullets as they flew past us, were so sudden that I looked around expecting to see half the men fall dead, and as we had been

78
in the bend of the little slough, until it became fully dark. when I ordered the men out and at a quick pace we marched back on our own trail passing the fire line and the burnt grass land beyond and did not stop until we had travelled about 3 miles. and it is believed that we passed out from that position unperceived by them. for we found ourselves entirely clear and the Country free in that direction as far as we desired to go.  We rested and listened for some little time. and hearing no Indians except those above, we turned off to the Eastward and made a Circuitous route around the fires leaving them far to our left & fell upon Silvers River a short distance below Camp. again waded the River and arrived at Camp at 2 oclock in the Morning having been absent 20 hours in which we had travelled 45 miles without rest. and seven hours of that time and about one third of the distance travelled exposed to a heavy fire from great odds!  We had a few Cartridges left, had fired over 300 shots and the Indians had fired many times that number and while they had wounded Alexander Griffin and Thomas F. Smith, we had counted 15 Indians

of Indians in front and concealed in the grass on every side

   This was the day fixed upon for the remainder of our Command to come in from Indian springs and it was in vain that we listened for some sound that would indicate an approaching reinforcement
   If the men at Camp had not heard our firing or the continued war whoops of the Indians they had certainly seen the prarie on fire at which I thought they would readily understand that all was not right and immediately send out a detachment, but it appeared that we were destined to to [sic] work out our own salvation and safety without aid or assistance from Camp
   The object of the Indians was evidently as soon as dark set in to place themselves in a position. so that if we moved at all we would be directly betwixt them and the blazing fire which was now illuminating the prarie. which would give them every advantage over us. for while they would thus be able to take deliberate aim at us, they would be invisible in darkness beyond the immediate glare of light
  We remained in our position where we had thrown ourselves

79
from the direction where we was expected to be. But after much discussion the Lieut had come to the Conclusion that we had probably had a fight and of course the result was uncertain. and from the fires, and from the Indians riding up toward camp on horseback he was of the opinion we had been defeated & probably cut off. but would send out a searching party in the morning in case we did not arrive before

   I have previously had considerable experience with hostile Indians in various ways, but have no hesitation in saying that for energy and persistence these Indians today far exceeded any others I have known on the Pacific Coast and it is Providential that we escaped with so few casualties
  After all necessary arrangements had been been [sic] made for the night I lay down inside of our little fortification and was surprised to find myself so nearly exhausted
  Up to this moment I had not once thought about being tired but the cares and responsibilities removed, I found myself so completely used up as to be scarcely able to move.  I have orders to the Sergt of the guard to wake me immediately if any danger appeared during the night

that we were certain had been killed. while many others were wounded and many horses crippled.

   We found upon arriving at Camp that the remainder of the Command had come in as we had expected, that a number of Indian horsemen had approached Camp in the fore part of the evening and been fired upon by the Sentinel.
   Proper steps and precautions were taken for defense in case of an attack during the night an event which we thought might happen
   The men at camp had seen the fires on the prarie and varied had been the speculations as to our probable fate,
   I left Sergt Mulvany in charge of the Camp in the morning, and as the fires were seen on the prarie late in the evening in the direction we had gone and us not returning he urged Lieut Applegate who had come in from Indian Springs to give him a few men and let him strike out and ascertain whether we required aid or not. and again urged the necessity of such a movement after the Indian horsemen had approached

80
fighting Indians were all that inhabited this whole region of country, and my view of the Indian business was if that was the extent of their numbers it would not be likely for me to jump them all up in one band. and if such an event should occur, I would expect with 12 resolute men to easily defeat them or fight our way successfully out of any snarl in which they might accidently envelope us. and it was not until we were actually surrounded by double that number that I could realized the fact that all those Cavalry officers were mistaken and therefore with this little band of scouts we were exposed to a more terrible scourge and required to fight much harder to save our scalps. than if the figures of Capt Curry and others had been correct

   In a Military point of view terrible outrages were perpetrated upon [?"Casup?] Tactics" yet I doubt very much if any troops however well drilled, were ever more obedient to their officers over them. which drove them back hastily, out of range.  The smoke of the guns and reports were seen and heard at Camp and I sent 15 men on foot at once to their assistance in case anyone had been accidentally wounded but all escaped injury

   I set a portion of the men at work on our fortification at sunrise, and the repairs being soon after completed. the detail was sent out to dislodge the Indians on the Mountain side. where the horsemen had been fired at. but it appeared that they had fired and then mounted their horses and left
   The wind commenced blowing briskly at about 9 A.M. and from down the vally. and very soon after fires were set on the prairies at various points in that direction & swept up the Vally through the grass. sage. and Tules & the atmosphere was thick with smoke
   The men outside find no Indians except a few mounted now & then whom the[y] could not approach near enough to shoot seeing the huge volumes of smoke around our Camp. fearing we were attacked. returned to camp about noon

Sunday Sept 24 1865
Just as I had got nicely to sleep last night, an alarm was given by a gun or two being fired by Sentinels and a general cry of "the Indians are coming".  the night was clear bright starlight & extremely frosty

  In a moment all hands were up & had positions within or [sic] sod fortification ready to sweep back any combination of forces the Indians might bring against us. but no attack was made.  a few Indians had rode at full gallop in sight of the Sentinel who had fired. but run the faster after they was fired at:  Simultaneously with daylight signal fires were seen at different points on the Mts surrounding the valley, and a camp fire appeared at the foot of the mountains about 2½  miles S.W. of camp & Seeing a few Indian horsemen near there, I ordered 5 of the team mules (which had been used in moving our men from Indians Springs) to be saddled and sent as many men out to reconnoitre, as the men approached the Indians rode up the side of the Mountain and took position in the rocks at the top. and the men had no better judgment than to ride up within easy gun shot of them, and a volley was fired at them from the rocks above

82
Wednesday Sept 27th 1865
Two of the Sentinels fired at Indians last night, alarming the Camp as such events generally do.  At each alarm the men were turned out of their blankets and assigned to positions to defend. but no disturbance took place and no dead Indians were found where the firing had been done
Thursday Sept 28 1865
As the most of the men needed rest. we lay in camp today.  The days being bright and warm & the nights Cold & heavy frosty
Friday Sept 29 1865
Sent out two detachments today one up the River & the other below both returned in the evening finding nothing
Saturday Sept 30 1865
Today with 25 men I struck off Eastward & fell upon the Eastern arm of the River about 5 miles off and passing the Rancherie where Lieut Bowen had surprised the Indians and taken their ponies on the 11 and we only regretted that we did not have the opportunity that was offered him to strike an effective

We fancied they were preparing for an attack, smoke and ashes filled the air so that Indians might have approached very near without being seen and to guard the camp we put out pickets & kept them posted until the smoke passed away in the P.M

Monday Sept 25 1865
Believing that the Indians were in force on the River below. I set out at daylight with 40 men and proceeded down the river with a detachment on each side for 12 miles to the Meadows above Malheur Lake, and returned to camp by passing over Mountains along the West side of the Valley;  We saw Indian tracks everywhere but no Indians
Tuesday Sept 26 1865
The pack train which had moved our Command from Indian springs being anxious to return I sent it back today with an escort of 15 men under Lt Applegate       

   While with 10 men I scouted down the River 7 miles and returned in the evening discovering no new signs made since the fight on the 23d

blow at enemy.  We found many Lodges. but all had been abandd. recently. Lieut Grant had also returned.  He had been as far as Fort Vancouver.  With him Dr. W. A. Tompkins who had been assigned to this expedition

Sunday Oct 1 1865
I had not yet positively fixed upon any locality for Winter Quarters.  Wood water and hay for the stock were the requisites:  The N.E. part of the vally furnished wood and water but no hay.  The vally below our camp furnished good hay in abundance & plenty of water, but no wood except willows

   I took Lieut Bowen and 10 men of the Cavalry and went across to the N.E. side of the plain and it was found that good pine timber could be had from the Mountain back of the vally. and nice water was furnished from the little branches which run down into

83
the level plain and [?sink?].   At an earlier period good hay might been secured but at this late season we considered the hay prospects anything but flattering

  Had the expedition been organized two months earlier no difficulty would been encountered in locating a Camp in this vicinity where wood, timber, water and hay all might been obtained:  We halted for noon on a small branch and picketed our horses. but soon after discovered a [?dime?] smoke rising suddenly just below our camp and from that Circumstance we thought that the Indians were hovering around camp or preparing to attack us upon our return,  We were about 15 miles from Camp and set out at once upon our return. laying our course for the point of willows where Silvers River divides above our camp. after a long stretch we reach the point and crossed over on to the point of land between the two Rivers, and instantly discovered a smoke pushing its way up through the willows about 50 yards from us on the most western of the two streams
   The men were in line. myself on the lead riding a mule.  I ordered a charge upon the brush at once which was quick and effective

84
faithful one. but productive of nothing.  The fire had probably been set by a straggler who had likely left immediately afterwards
Tuesday Oct 3d 1865
To day after seriously contemplating our situation I find our position about as follows:  We have in the Command about 130 men. 30 cavalry and the remainder Infantry. sufficient men for a splendid expedition:  30 Cavalry horses all poor and unfit for service:  Capt Small of Camp Watson Could furnish me no transportation.

   The order creating this expedition directed him to turn over to me all the pack animals which could be spared from that Camp. and I was not disappointed when I found he had none to spare:
   Lieut Bowen was ordered to bring all the pack animals that could be spared from Willow Creek. but he had no animals except a few belonging to Camp Watson and those had to be returned there
    Capt Scott of the 4th Cal Infantry who was now at Indian Springs {?whi?] he had named Camp Curry had been ordered to turn over to us 15 pack mules ad 12 team mules which appeared to be about all the transportation I had any hope of obtaining at this late season

One Indian only was found & he was instantly killed & his Camp and fishing tackle and about 10 bushels of fish were captured

   The River at this season of the Year is very low. and this Indian had availed himself of a Beaver Dam to establish his fishery. which was conducted principly with Willow basket nets.  the fishery was destroyed and the camp demolished:
  From the vast amount of fish a person would have thought this fellow had been there some time. but with a small detacht I was at this very identical spot on the 21st & no Indians or fishery was established here at that time:  We reached Camp a little after dark;  The fires below on the river could not be accounted for, that Indians had set them during the day was certain

Monday Oct  2d 1865
At 2 oclock this morning I set out with 25 Infantry & 15 cavalry down the River where the fires were still burning.  at daylight we was at a point in the River where we believed the Indians might be found providing there were any there.  our search was a

possible chance for us to obtain grain from that Camp for our animals unless there should be a surplus on hand for theirs which event is not likely to occur.  Therefore our main dependence is in the hay we will be able to secure

  This is a point about 12 miles above Malheur Lake. and about 3 miles above the broad and expansive meadows on Silvers River where any amount of frost bitten hay can be cut, and if he weather remains favorable we will be able to secure a sufficient quantity for winter use; A detail of men were made and armed and equipped with muskets. bayonets, Scythes & whetstones were dispatched at once to the Meadows below;  The nearest timber suitable for building purposes is 20 miles away on the Mountain on the North side of the vally:  We therefore soon concluded that comfortable quarters could be made of sods cut in the [?] and form of an adobe & laid up in the form of a brick wall:  dirt roofs are Common in all the settled portion of the County West of the Rocky Mts
  Lumber for doors was dispensed with and a frame work made of Willows and covered with a beef hide was believed to be a good substitute for lumber, and a further conclusion was that the ground was as good a floor as a soldier wanted

vicinity 2 months earlier we might have located a Camp where more conveniences for building could been obtained;  Men were detailed to cut sod. to haul them. to lay them up &c. & quite an extensive preparation was made
Wednesday Oct 4th 1865
The weather is lovely, pleasant days but cold freezing nights

  All hands busily engaged at their different branches of business

Thursday Oct 5 1865
Temporary "Wick-iups" are prepared by the men.  Generally large enough for two persons & are formed on a level in two lines paralel to each other about 20 steps apart. while I have a small "Wall Tent" in which I sleep and do the writing for the Company and keep the Records & papers of the Expedition
Friday Oct 6 1865
The walls of our buildings were commenced today in good earnest.  the parade ground was laid off just 75 yards square. and in such a manner that the 4 angles indicated the 4 cardinal points

86
Saturday Oct 7 1865

  Being anxious to engage the Indians which we believed now to be on the opposite side of the Lakes. I set out at sundown with 30 Infy & 20 cav  on a scout with a view of crossing the Tule Swale or arm of Harney Lake where the Indian horsemen had crossed to attack the Scouts on the 23d ult:  We reached the place indicated after travelling about 10 miles. and taking Lieut Bowens horse I rode in some 50 yds through water. mud and mire & finally it was with much difficulty that I succeeded in reaching dry ground:  The Slough or Tule channel appeared to be very nearly if not quite a mile in width, and the 14 horsemen who brought on the fight with us on the 23d Sept had crossed at this place. they had probably wallowed through swimming themselves & horses when necessary to do so
   I soon became convinced that we would be unable to cross with our Pack mules and Cavalry horses therefore proceeded down the slough west towards Harney Lake and camped at 2 oclock in the morning:

Sunday Oct 8th 1865
Proceeded down to Harney Lake

and halted & unpacked our Animals and rested for two or three hours and then returned to Camp Wright our Camp which had thus been named in memory of Genl Wright who had been lost on board the Steamer "Brother Jonathan" in July last between Sanfranciso & Ogn. whither he was coming to assume Command of this Dept
Oct 9-10-11-12-13-14-&15 Steady at work in camp
Monday Oct 16 1865
This morning the detail of men set out at an early  hour for the meadows as usual, and at about 10 oclock the teams were sent down to haul up the hay which had been cut:

  In about an hour I noticed a heavy volume of dust in the direction of the meadows, and with the aid of the spy glass I could see the two wagons coming in the distance as fast as the mules could run. and the Wagon master on horseback a short distance in advance riding at full speed, he soon rode up & reported that the Indians had attacked them and driven them back, that

87
they had had a hard ran of it and had barely saved their teams from falling into the Indians hands.  that there were 20 or 30 Indians who had charged upon them. when he had turned the wagons around & run for camp:

   I waited to hear no more for 6 of my men had gone down to the meadows in the morning and were either dead or in need of immediate assistance:  I was alarmed for their safety.  I hoped they may have been able to gain a position in the Willows or somewhere else where the [sic] could hold out until relief could reach them:  The Cav horses were near camp & I ordered Lieut Bowen to mount 15 of his men as quick as possible. and hasten with all speed to the rescue of the hay cutters, while I called for 15 Infy. and set out in a moment in double quick time and met the wagons a short distance from Camp;  The drivers and the soldiers who were detailed to load the hay all confirmed the report that there were 30 or 40 mounted Indians, that they had charged upon them, but no one had heard any firing from the Meadows
  I ordered the wagons about at once and the soldiers were mounted therein. and I [?....ted?] the teamsters to drive as fast in

88
this was all that had been seen by the teamsters, and these 6 men with their arms stacked neared them had been transformed by Mihrage [sic] or [?M.....h?] more likely an excited imagination into 30 or 40 mounted Indians begrimed with paint. armed to the teeth who had charged upon the wagons and came near capturing the teams & killing the drivers

  This is one of those invariable results of timid people jumping at hasty conclusions that objects are Indians before they are positive of that fact and fear and an agitated excitement quickly steps in and finishes the work by transforming any small object into a formidable foe
   The hay makes [sic] had noticed the peculiar movements of the team with some curiosity and were not a little surprised to see the wagons return at so rapid a rate filled with soldiers
  The excitement over we stopped on the River bank, and the day warm & men dusty all hands took a bath & soon after set out on our return to camp, and in about one mile we met Lieut Bowen with the Cavalry coming in the Oregon Cav style in a very slow walk
   It may possibly be "Military" to ride as slow as possible when men are in danger, and relying upon you for assistance, but if

the opposite direction which was done. for the teamsters whipped the mules without mercy and they run at a furious speed the wagons clattered and the dust raised in little clouds.  If a mule lagged, the whip was freely applied.  No sympathy for mules at such a time as this for a half dozen men were in danger. this was sufficient to render Mule flesh a secondary Consideration.  The men were excited & anxious to meet the Indians and rescue the men.

  We were fast approaching the place where the teams had been charged upon, the mules foaming with sweat. the men becoming more eager and of course every eye turned in the direction where the Indians had been seen
     They were soon "discovered" the Wagon Master saw them & the teamsters saw them, and there came a simultaneous cry from all hands "there they are" "they are coming". and looking steadily in the direction indicated, instead of 30 or 40 mounted Indians there were our haymakers about a mile and a half off quietly mowing hay with their arms stacked near them, and

So the "Cavalry Tactics" might be considerably improved:   It was expected the Cav would be ready to start with but few moments delay that they would rush to the place where the Indians had been seen and rescue the hay cutters. and that the detacht of Infy would perhaps be in time to assist them in the fight if it should prove to be an obstinate one, but sad would been the fate of any small detacht who might been dependent upon the Cavalry force that day:  I returned to Camp vexed, & in fact very mad and penciled out General order No 9

   The alarm, although a false one rendered it certain to the minds of all, that a half dozen of our Men were in danger and that a great activity on our part was required to save them from Massacre
   This was a fine specimen of those false alarms so common in an Indian Country, and which should be met at all times with the same energy and activity of action as if they were not such, for men who are ready to hastily conclude that an alarm is false (which is too often the case) are liable at any time to suffer a small party of men to be massacred when it is their sacred duty to rescue and protect them

89
Nothing unusual occurred. except the daily routine of Camp work until the 31
Tuesday October 31 1865
Lieut Grant the H. A. Q. M reported the completion of quarters today, they were inspected and found to be anything but pleasant quarters for 130 men to winter but were as comfortable [?]  was as could be expected under the circumstances.  The days are remarkably pleasant and nights freezing cold:  The hay cutters had been relieved by a man coming in with a Mowing Machine who took a Contract to cut and stack a sufficient quantity for our winters use
Wednesday Nov  1 1865
With 18 Infy I went on a scout over to the North side of the Vally to see if any Indians were encamped up that, also to see if a few boards could be split out. and to [?] a flag staff;  the flag staff & boards were obtained but no Indians were discovered.  We returned, on the 5th
Monday Nov 6 1865
Upon my return I recd information that Capt Scott from Camp Curry had been on a scout to

[lithograph duplicated covering page 90 which is transcribed on next page]
Stanley Del            Sarony, Major & Knapp Liths 449 Broadway N.Y.

the South side of Haney Lake with 60 men. that he had succeeded in breaking up several Ranches. had killed one Indian, and taken a squaw prisoner who afterwards escaped; and had lost one man. who had fell behind the command; the Indians watching the troops from the highlands had discovered this man far in the rear had pounced upon him. killed him. cut him to pieces stretching his entrails out upon the sage brush;  The command had returned from the Scout to Camp Curry without going around the Lake

   I had for some time been contemplating going round the Lakes, but had concluded to postpone the trip until the snows of winter had fallen which would render it almost certain that the winter supplies laid in by the Indians could be destroyed, and the Indians killed or captured.  But as they now been disturbed and would probably seek winter quarters somewhere else, I ordered a scout in that direction to start tomorrow around the East end of Malheur Lake

90
Tuesday Nov 7 1865
I set out with 20 Infy & 20 Cav and proceeded across the sage plain East of us. leaving the E. end of Malheur Lake to our right and passing through a low gap in the Mts we fell upon a small tributary of Malheur River about 25 Miles and camped at 10 oclock P.M.
Wednesday Nov 8th 1865
At daylight I was out with small detacht in different directions upon and down the little vally searching for Indians. but failed to find any fresh sign:

   At about 10 A.M. we set out S.W. through the hills and at about 7 Miles we fell upon the East end of the Lake and there Westerly along the S. side a few miles and camped on the margin a little after dark

Thursday Nov 9 1865
No fires were allowed last night as we were expecting to find Indian Ranches early this Morning which we did find but they had been deserted two or three days

   Malheur Lake derives its name from Malheur River. which for many years was supposed to have its source in the Lake. but upon more thorough exploration it is found that a low range of sage

91
favorite season for water fowl. and the abundance of Swan. geese, brants, pelicans, ducks of every variety. white & blue cranes, gulls. Snipe of various kinds sizes and colors & plovers. can scarcely be concieved! and the vast cloud of aquatic birds of all kinds moving through the air, and the Continual cry and scream of each variety combined to make such Music as no pen can describe:  In the Lake wherever the open water appeared it was one complete mass of fowls. so much so that often for a half mile an opening could not be seen between them:  The long necked swan appeared to be by far the largest bird among this vast multitude of aquatics. and it was amusing to see a flock of Swans fly along on the surface in their efforts to rise. running over flocks of geese and ducks which happened to be before them.  the smaller birds, flying, dodging or diving under water to avoid the swan, which would pass over them the same as if they were so many flys upon the surface.

    We set out from Camp this morning at day light, Westerly along the Slough and at about 9 miles we came to a large spring gushing out of the bluffs and within

hills seperate [sic] the waters of the Lake from those of the River;

   The Lake is shallow and nearly level with the surrounding plain.  Malheur Lake is a vast swamp filled with grass flags and Tules and the water strongly impregnated with alkali.  Open water appears in places of half mile or more in extent and some times more - while the Lake and swamp on the North side is perhaps 6 or 7 miles in extent in that direction while as it extends westward, it gradually narrows into a swale or swamp or Water [?] high tules of some one or two miles in width, with small spaces of open water & thickets of tules alternating:  This channel extends to Harney Lake some miles to the westward
   The Indians crossed this channel to fight the scouts on Sept 23d, but up to this time we have been unable to find any practicable place for crossing
   On the south side of the Lake and slough, is a narrow strip of level sage land extending back a half a mile or more to the foot of the low hills
   This appears to be the

92
and Camped at the lower margin of Tule swamp land which appears to extend up stream several miles from here.
Friday Nov 10th 1865
The men and animals requiring rest we remained at this camp today. and little parties were sent out to explore the Valley in the vicinity of Camp:

  The deserted Indian Camps were numerous.  generally some distance back from the stream built very temporarily under the lie of a thick Sage bush in such a manner as to be unnoticeible [sic] unless you pass within a few feet of them:  A thick bunch of sage is selected and a quantity of Rye grass is gathered and with the assistance of smaller sage  brush a kind of wall is made to protect in the form of a semicircle to protect them from the prevailing winter winds, and in this little temporary before a small fire a family of Indians will pass away the miserably cold weather, seldom guarding against rain in any manner whatever:
   We found the tracks of [?ten?] Indians in the sand where they had been prowling around

about ¼ mile of the Mouth of Thunder River, coming in from the South.  About which place the enemy will  expected to be found in full force, but after a thorough examination of the Country around about we were only able to find where 2 footmen had been during the night or very early this morning and their tracks appeared to be turned in the direction of Steins Mountain some 25 or 30 miles south

   We retired to the spring mentioned above and cooked our breakfast. and soon after set out up the River on the East side in a course ue south or nearly so, deserted ranches appearing at short intervals, and a few fresh Moccasin tracks occasionally were seen in the trails but nothing to indicate that there was any considerable force of Indians near here at present
   Thunder River is a deep sluggish stream with Muddy bans and about 50 feet wide rises in Steins Mountain some 30 or 40 Miles off S.Westerly
   We followed up this stream about 12 miles following the well beaten trails and passing many deserted camps, and finally crossed over to the opposite side

93
We came to a beautiful dry alkali pond about ¼ mile in extent. with an incrustation of pure snow white Salratus about ¼ inch thick over the surface. but no animals or Indians or the tracks or sign of either were to be found:  We galopped [sic] our horses over the pond but Could raise no dust. and the surface appeared so solid that that [sic] the horses hoofs did not make impressions over ½ inch deep:  We were now more puzzled than ever but our minds were soon relieved by a slight and scarcely perceptible puff of air from a deep ravine on the west and at once the find alkali dust rose in a little cloud from the surface of the little pond.  the mystery was solved and we returned to camp

   In one of the deserted ranches today we found the hair of two white persons. one of dark color & the other light and both very fine. the light colored hair had more the appearance of that of a young girl than of a grown person
   The water above appears to be spread out over a vast surface. of Tules, flags, & marsh or swamp grass. while at or just below our camp their [sic] appears to be a fall of 6 or 8 feet into

last night. with a view of Stealing some of our pack mules. but could not find where they had gon  [sic] or from whence they had come

   During the day a brisk white dust was discovered by the Sentinel. on the West side of the Valley and above. About 3 miles from Camp:  The air was calm. the dust would  raise at short periods and fill the air and soon after settle down. and various was the conjectures in regard to its cause, the air being still it could not be caused by the wind.  It remained in the same locality therefore was not likely to be Indians or wild animals. yet it appeared to continue regular at short intervals
   Some pronounced it Indians, others antelope, and others thought it to be Sand hill cranes Wallowing in the dust. and as to myself I was unable to determine what did cause it and to solve the mystery I took 5 Cavalry men and rode over to see for myself what there was to be discovered:  The dust was in a little cove at the foot of the Mts.  We approached the place cautiously, every man in readiness to meet an enemy, but instead of finding Indians or birds or wild animals

a muddy canal which continues down to the mouth of the River.  and we doubt much if a practicable Crossing exists between this point & the mouth
Saturday Nov 11 1865
This morning we set out for Harney Lake in a course a little north of west crossing several small muddy streams near camp which appear to be mere outlets of the swamp above. several of the Pack Mules miring down and course rolling over in the mud and. water wetting the packs as much as possible as mules usually do. but we soon reached the foot hills and ascended a low ridge to the summit. and thence by a gradual descent down a ravine for five or six miles when we found ourselves on a level sage plain on the South side of Harney Lake and about a mile from the beach.  Continuing along westerly with a small Lake of about a ½ miles in extent to our left, gradually drawing nearer and nearer to until we found ourselves on the beah [sic] of Harney Lake

   Harney Lake is a handsome sheet of water. deep and green colored about 8 miles long E&W about 5 wiles wide N.&S.   Was named after Gen Harney of the U.S. Army
   Along the East side of the Lake appears a ridge of drifting sand a few feet high, and a narrow and deep channel breaks through said ridge & suddenly expands into the Tuly swamp of one mile or more in width extending Eastward to Malheur Lake
   At this point Capt Currys Command in 1864 experienced much difficulty and inconvenience in not being able to cross this Channel:  The water of the Lake is Salt and strongly impregnated with Alkali and is wholly unfit for use.
  Many brisk little streams are running into the Lake. besides Silver Creek. Thunder River & Silvies River yet the Lake has no outlet
  Pleastons Butte an isolated conical mountain rises abruptly from the plain a few miles West of the West end of the Lake

Sunday Nov 12 1865
It rained a little towards morning and we find it very chilly and disagreeable with a cold wind from the S.W.

  We set out at an early hour passing through a section of Marshland bordering the Lake on the West, crossing several rapid little streams & Came to Silver Creek. which at this season of the year has a deep broad channel, but no water.  We continued through the sage plain & reached Camp Wright a little after dark. the Men tired and weary, having made a long march of over 30 miles
  The distance travelled on this Scout in 5 travelling days has been 110 miles which is rather a wearisome avarage [sic] for Infantry

Rained all last night. today cold. wind S.W.

Rained steady all night and continued during the day with snow

Hd Qrs S. R. Expedition Camp Wright Agn Nov 13th 1865
L L Williams Capt 1st Ogn Infy Comdg Expedition
Letter Recommending Bloodhounds to trace out hostile Indians
Hd Qrs Silvies River Expedition
Camp Wright Oregon Nov 13th 1865
Sir
I would most respectfully call the attention of the Comdg Officer to Dpt of the Columbia to the great difficulty that is likely to be encountered by Troops in searching out  and destroying the few renegade Indians of this County after the principle bands are broken up:  It has already become a matter of difficulty to find any Indians within the jurisdiction of this command while it is not unfrequently the case that an Indian track or two may be found where they have been prowling around during the night.  To relieve the Troops in the field from great embarrassment and to insure the extermination or capture of the last remnant of the hostile tribes of Oregon during the summer of 1866 I would most earnestly recommend that Bloodhounds from the Southern States be brought to this Country and employed to search out the Savages in their mountain fortresses where it is impossible for the genius of man to follow their footsteps or trace them to their rocky retreat
I am Very Respectfully Your Obt Servt  L L Williams  Capt 1st Ogn Infy Cmdg Expedition
Cmdg Officer Dpt of Columbia Ft Vancouver WT

intermixed.  A little after dark a poor emaciated and wretched looking man came in to camp

   He was dressed in rags and nearly famished with hunger & appeared to be almost chilled to death.  his voice trembled and his reason appeared to have almost departed.  he could give but a confused idea of his wanderings, but sufficient information was obtained to learn that he had left Jordan creek in the [?Oraghill?] Country about 100 miles S.S.E from here some 10 or twelve days ago with a view of going to some point on Snake River that his horse had strayed off from his Camp and in a vain attempt to find his horse he had lost his camp and had been wandering about without fire or blankets. or gun. and nothing to eat.  fortunately he had not been discovered by the Indians 
   If he had not reached our Camp as he did, he could not possibly have survived another night.   He was taken in and properly cared for. with a view of sending him to the settlements at the first opportunity

Wednesday Nov 15 1865
Wind blowed furiously from the West all day

pens, pencils, papers and envelopes every where. the tent being wet and its weight together with the pressure of the pelting storm without, appeared likely to keep me prostrated in this very unpleasant predicament when suddenly the force of the wind caught the under part of the tent and as instantaneously as the pop of a pistol, it was torn loose from its fastening and carried away like a little cloud & my table, books, records & papers and every thing else pertaining to head quarters appeared to follow in the same wake.

  It was certainly no time for reflection so snatching up a blanket which appear to be the only thing left I caught by the 4 corners & set out in an interesting chase & with the aid of a few of the men who had come to the rescue, I succeeded in gathering up my principal books and papers pitched them into the blanket wet and muddy and hastily conveyed them to quarters
   After the violence of the storm had subsided I went out in search of other papers but without much success

Thursday Nov 30 1865
The ground was covered with about an inch of snow this morning. a light drizzling rain set in and rained the snow off by noon.  heavy wind from the west during the afternoon:
At about 4 oclock P.M. the herders Came rushing in with only a portion of the horses.  They reported that a dozen Indians had rushed upon them and had succeeded in running off 9 head of the animals.  Lieut Bowens fine horse among the number. that the Indians were well mounted and armed,  This misfortune took

place on the River about 1 mile above camp. and it was not likely that the Indians could be overtaken unless by accident.  I called out 15 Infy at once and started after them.  At the same time ordering Lieut Bowen to mount a few men upon his best horses and quickly follow after;

  We was soon at the place where the Indians had stolen the animals & fell upon their trail and by this time the Cav had come up, and I started them on the trail of the Inds but it soon became dark & we returned to camp

   The ground was frozen solid and with a detail of about 25 men Cav & Infy I set out on the trail of our stolen horses and followed up the River by a tortuous route crossing over to the East side near the head of the Vally

this point until nearly dark & we camped in the Willows above having travelled over 20 miles.  We found by their tracks that there were only 4 Indians. and the probability is that the herders were careless and had no knowledge of their presence until they dashed upon a few of the horses the farthest from them.  It was a ridiculous affair to let 4 Indians steal 9 horses out of a band in the day time in an open plain. while the herders were mounted or had their horses saddled & ready for immediate use near by them.  It would been much more soldierly to have pursued & recovered the horses or killed some of the thieves
Saturday Dec 2 1865
Snowed during the night. wind becoming a gale this morning from N.W.  We followed the Indian trail dimly visible Eastward along the foot of the Mountains bordering the Valley about 15 miles & camped in a small stream coming in from the left.   The frozen ground and light snow prevented us from finding any further traces of the Indians whatever.  We therefore abandoned the pursuit and made a cold camp with small green willow brush for fuel:  Heavy cold wind all day

Wednesday Dec 6 1865
At 10 A.M we set out 25 Infy of my Company, and 10 Cavalry on foot in consequence of their horses becoming poor and unserviceable, to try the Much talked of and dreaded realities of the "Winter campaign".  our destination the head waters of the Malheur River

   The morning was clear and very cold.  We struck across the sage vally in a course about N. 30º E. and travelled 20 miles and camped on the same stream where we had camped Dec 3d on the N.E side of the vally

Thursday Dec 7 1865
Night cold. morning calm. snow 3 inches deep & stream frozen solid.  we followed the Canyon about 4 miles where we ascended the Mountain on the left & immediately entered heavy pine timber where the snow appeared about 10 inches deep. passing over a high summit ridge and down a timbered ravine. we fell upon a stream 8 or 10 feet wide running Easterly to the Malheur River.

   Upon this stream we camped in 4 inches of snow and no grass for our animals

Friday Dec 8 1865
About an inch of snow fell last night and then turned cold and all hands passed an unpleasant night.  We started out down the

Sunday Dec 3 1865
Last night was a cold one some of the men slept cold & many of them did not sleep at all.  Ice frozen in the stream so as to bear up footmen.
We started for Camp Wright at an early hour in a straight course across the Sage Vally 18 miles distant where we arrived at sundown.
When the animals were stolen our pack train had gone to to Camp Curry without an escort and in the moving of the 1  I had sent Lieut Applegate  with an escort of 15 men to meet the train & he arrived simultaneous with us this evening and reported that the Indians had run off some of the animals at that Camp
Monday Dec 4 & 5
Heavy N.W. winds
The object of this expedition being to prosecute a winter campaign against the Indians  , and our instructions had been to prosecute the same vigorously, and this appearing to be a favorable time to try the experiment.  I issued an order for 25 men of the Infantry an [sic] 10 dismounted men of the Cav  under Lieut Bowen to be in readiness on the 6th for a "winters" scout of of [sic]  15 day  to the Malheur River

Stream and after travelling about a half mile we entered a rocky Canyon or gorge which proved to be impassable for the pack train yet practicable for footmen

  I proposed to send a portion of the men down the Canyon and the remainder over the snowy Mts on the left and form a junction in the stream at some point below and for choice Lieut Bowen and 22 men went down the stream   I passed over the Mountain with the train and remainder of the Detacht
  After travelling about 9 miles easterly passing out of the pine timber into Juniper & sage hills we fell upon the creek and followed it down through a little vally about 2 miles farther to its entrance into the Middle fork of the Malheur River at which point we camped at 2 oclock P.M. the River being about 100 feet wide & frozen over so that men could pass up & down on the ice
   As the afternoon wore away all eyes were often directed up the little stream, but could see nothing of Lieut Bowen & his men, and they failed to come in tonight
