  We remained in Camp today and scouted about in the vicinity. and about 2 miles above  connected the scout with the scout from near Canyon City in July lst:  A short distance below camp on the left bank of the River we discovered a large spring of boiling hot water.  flowing out, of the bank into the river clearing the ice for some distance below

[Sun]day Dec 10 1865
Started out this morning in a blustering snow storm, down stream in an East course, and travelled about 8 miles through canyons and narrow bottoms, and encamped in the willows and sent out a small detacht down River a mile or so & also scouted up a small vally on the N side of the river a few miles

  An abundance of Indian sign about a month old. but none which appeared more recent

[duplicate of transcription 2 pages earlier]
Stream and after travelling about a half mile we entered a rocky Canyon or gorge which proved to be impassable for the pack train yet practicable for footmen

  I proposed to send a portion of the men down the Canyon and the remainder over the snowy Mts on the left and form a junction in the stream at some point below and for choice Lieut Bowen and 22 men went down the stream   I passed over the Mountain with the train and remainder of the Detacht
  After travelling about 9 miles easterly passing out of the pine timber into Juniper & sage hills we fell upon the creek and followed it down through a little vally about 2 miles farther to its entrance into the Middle fork of the Malheur River at which point we camped at 2 oclock P.M. the River being about 100 feet wide & frozen over so that men could pass up & down on the ice
   As the afternoon wore away all eyes were often directed up the little stream, but could see nothing of Lieut Bowen & his men, and they failed to come in tonight

Saturday Dec 9 1865
The weather moderated somewhat &

101
anxious to stop at night and equally so to start again in the morning
Wednesday Dec 13 1865
Colder than usual. snow several inches deep. had travelled about 3 miles. when coming to the mouth of a ravine Several smokes were discovered about a half mile up the ravine up towards the mountains to our right:  Dropping back a few steps I took 15 men & hastened along the table lands to the right to a point opposite where the smokes had been seen. and from there approached the ravine to be disappointed at finding them to rise from a cluster of hot springs. the vapor having so much the appearance of smoke. that it was difficult to determine that it was not smoke until sufficiently to notice that fact by actual observation:

   Still following down stream we found immediately below. a tremendous deep and dark looking Canyon formed by black & scoriated walls of Basalt through which the River passes;
    I      passed over the high Mts on the left and Lieut Bowen passed down with the Pack train on the right of the River;  From the high summits on the left we could see the Mouth of the South fork of Malheur a short distance below, which was only

Monday Dec 11 1865
We made about 9 miles today cold N.W. wind & snow squally all day
Tuesday Dec 12 1865
Night calm. still and extremely cold. our blankets frozen solid and rattle like boards. and from the small amount of wood. and the cold weather it is difficult to keep up sufficient fire for cooking & warming purposes  The men sleep cold. and their frozen blankets yield but little warmth   Rye grass and small willows are cut and spread down in the snow upon which our blankets are spread. fires are obliged to be kept up during the night

   Our pack mules 15 in number were actually unserviceable when we received them. they are very poor and some of them stagger as they walk along
   The men are continually Complaining of the many things that are not always agreeable to soldiers, yet amidst all their discomforts and complainings there is a general willingness manifested on the part of all
   We set  out and made a reasonable march down stream and camped on the right bank of the River to spend another miserable night.  hurry always

102 Camped on a stream about 6 feet wide. coming in from the N.W., at this place we found the tracks of two Indian horsemen. who appeared to have passed up and down the stream a time or two. as if hunting for ducks (the stream being open in places) and afterwards had gone back in the direction they had come, up the little stream at which we are camped;  The main stream, being formed by springs, which were seldom ever frozen, is kept open in places, in spite of the cold weather 
Friday Dec 15 1865
Still colder. we remained in Camp today. and with 15 of my most resolute men I set out into the Mountains up the stream in the direction the Indians appeared to have gone.  believing we would be able to come upon the winter Camp in some secluded spot near by

   We soon come upon three deserted camps.  which apparently had been occupied for Some, but had been abandoned about two days.  A few horses had been feeding over the hills in the immediate vicinity during their stay at this place:  Their trail was found leading of N.W. over the bleak barren hills. and was made by 6 or 7 horses and three

known in imagination from ideas formed from a knowledge of head branches;  Descending to within about a mile of the South fork we found ourselves in a deep rocky basin from which we could not easily extricate ourselves except by making a long and circuitous march back from the River or by following down a narrow and doubtful looking Canyon towards the River which appeared to enter the solid walls of the Mountains a few rods below

   Following down this canyon we found it to enter a very narrow & curious Gorge not over 6 feet wide at the bottom with perpendicular Walls on each side from 5 to 600 feet high. and not over 20 feet wide at the top:   This continued for about a mile in a tortuous route without any particular change in its general character when we suddenly found ourselves on the River bank and crossing over on the ice we camped on the South fork about a Mile from its Mouth

Thursday Dec 14 1865
Last night was more severe and cold than usual.  We proceeded up stream South Westerly, through a narrow bottom or vally the most of it [?] for about 12 miles and

103
Sunday Dec 17 1865
Last night was an uncomfortable one.  Our blankets become wet. and also our clothing during the rain of yesterday. and the snow was wet and sloppy underfoot;  We had gathered rye grass and fine willow bush to a certain extent to prevent ourselves from sleeping in the water on the ground, and had turned in with a prospect of no very sound sleep;  About 8 or 9 oclock in the evening. it cleared off and became cold and froze everything solid.   Our blankets were froze as hard as boards.  and the most of them underneath the men were frozen down solid to the ground. while many of the men myself among the number, found not only our blankets froze solid to the ground, but our breeches froze fast to our blankets   the wind was keen and cutting from the N.W. and it was a gloomy looking sight to see the men thaw themselves out. and prepare for a start this morning

   We continued up the small stream our poor pack mules tottering along as they went.  but the snow and water being frozen solid rendered it much more pleasant for the men than yesterday.  At about 7 miles we camp [sic] to the place of our camp of Nov 7 last, near the East end of the Malheur Lake valley, and at

Indians on foot.  We followed the trail until in the P.M. in hope we might have the good luck to find them encamped somewhere in the Mountain, but the atmosphere becoming more moderate it began snowing at about 9 A.M. and continued all day. and when it became necessary for us to abandon the trail and return to Camp, the trail could scarcely be seen at all:  We reached Camp long after dark.
Saturday Dec 16 1865
The storm subsided in the early part of the night. and the weather quite mild this morning we set out tolerable early up Stream. the snow about a foot deep., when the atmosphere became damp and it soon after began to rain and by a little P.M. it became wet and sloppy under foot - At about 2 oclock we left the main stream and followed up a more smaller branch Westerly towards Harney Lake Vally and in the direction of our camp & coming to a considerable of a bunch of Willows on the branch we camped for the night. wet & fatigued and but a poor prospect of becoming dry or comfortable during the night

104
night. at least half of the men were gathering brush all the time;  Sage brush makes a quick fire. is rather flashy, and burns quick. but soon burns out.  It is a favorite material for the Indians to make signal fires:  We made an early start and struck for camp Wright over the sage plain 15 miles due West

  This proved to be one of those few days experienced during a life time in which warmth cannot be sustained by bodily & physical exercise
  We were oftentimes obliged to stop and build fires to prevent the men from freezing. frost would whiten their hair and whiskers when standing around the fires. and icicles would form upon their mustaches in less than 15 minutes after leaving a fire.  and in  numerous instances it was found that they had become two or three inches in length while the men had been walking a couple of miles.  Several of the men became weak and exhausted consequently much delay in keeping them properly thawed out
   After a tedious. and cold days march we arrived at Camp Wright late in the P.M. to find that the Indians had been prowling around camp during our absence and on the night of the 11 had run off 11 head of our beef Cattle. and

this point we leave the waters of Malheur River, and pass over a low dividing range of hills into the level sage vally East of the Malheur Lake. following the margin of the plain        [?North?] and a short distance we bore off to the left and made our way to a large hot spring situated in the level sage plain about 2 1/2 miles from the foot hills on the East;  This spring is about 30 yards wide. nearly round forming a brisk little stream running North a short distance on the plain and sinks:

    Clouds of vapor & steam are generally seen rising from all these hot springs. and this has often been seen from Camp Wright its course being due East from that Camp and about 15 miles distant a level sage plain all the way
   It has been a severe cold day. men have suffered considerably and complained much of their frozen clothes and uncomfortable condition generally.

Monday Dec 18 1865
Much the coldest night of all (the coldest of the winter) but did not freeze the hot spring over.  We all slept cold;  Sage brush was plenty. and fires were kept up all

very singular to relate their trail had not been discovered for two or three days afterwards, and not until it had been very nearly obliterated by snow:

   Our Expedition is not supplied to a time when communication can be opened in the spring. and although we expect to be tolerable close run, this will Cause us to be still more short. while on the other hand if a hasty pursuit, had been made the animals might been recovered and probably some of the Indians might been killed. & if nothing more, they might been traced to their winter quarters where they could have been destroyed   They had gone in the direction of Steins Mountain, and are probably at this time feasting gaily upon our beef
   We saw many old ranches on the Scout. and numbers which had been abandoned about the time Camp Wright was established
   Saw a few deer tracks on the Mountains on the 7 of the month a few otter were seen on the Malheur also ducks. where open water appeared. Saw a number of Jackass Rabbits. some of them Snow white others gray.  Large gray wolves and Cayotes are to[?] everywhere and sage hens and prarie chickens are found along all the stream

 The Country generally barren. rocky and desolate. and much of the same character wherever you go.  It is rough and Mountainy. cut up with Canyons, gorges and deep ravines covered with bunch grass. and the hateful sage brush:  Lava. Basalt & Granite the principal rocks. much of the surface being Covered with broken lava.  Black obsidian. much resembling black bottle glass. the favorite [crossed out: point] rock from which arrow points are manufactured is found broken up and scattered over the surface everywhere
 

Tuesday Dec 19 1865
Last night was about as cold as the night before, and although in comfortable quarters. we found it about as miserable a night as any on the scout
Wednesday Dec 20 1865

 It snowed all night and continued until about noon today.  about 6 inches of new snow fell and we now have snow about a foot deep
 Much discussion has been had and much correspondence has taken place in regard to the transportation of our supplies from Camp Curry to this place
 Col. Curry who issued order No 7

106
according to my figuring. it would require them on the road just about all the time driving the remainder of the winter. hence our winter scouting was at an end and the real object of this expedition defeated. an energetic campaign during the few remaining winter months in all probability would been more effective in punishing the hostile Indians in South Eastern Oregon than had been done for several years, or is likely to be done for some time to come.
Friday Dec 22 1865
Snowed considerable during the night but settled down to about 6 inches during the day.  day still. & thick cloudy
Saturday Dec 23 1865
A severe cold night. began snowing at Reveille and continued until noon and then subsided and commenced thawing. wind SW.
Sunday Dec 24 1865
West wind. fine snow falling. day cold and very unpleasant.

of August 15th 1865 being then in Command of the Department which said order created this Expedition and also established Camp Curry. contemplated that the camp at Indian Springs (afterwards located by Capt Scott and by him named Camp Curry) should furnish transportation for our supplies from that point to this  But as Col Curry was relieved of his command of the Department soon afterwards and as Capt Scott had also been relieved and Mustered out of service. it was found when too late for remedy that we must do our own packing from that point to this which was certainly a great calamity. for we only had transportation sufficient to run one scouting party which I had intended to keep Constantly in the field during the winter, in search of Indians and break up their haunts at a time when it would be impossible for them to escape

   But as the orders were now interpreted differently by the Commdg officer at Camp Curry, it at once became necessary for us to employ all our force of animals. to pack our supplies from Camp Curry.  We had but 15 pack mules, and those so poor as to be able to pack but about half a load, therefore

Monday Dec 25
No change from yesterday. snow appears to fall very light & settles down. or wastes away about as fast as it falls
Tuesday Dec 26 1865
Snowed all night. Wind west the drifts were banked up several feet high around our buildings. the poor Sentinels on post suffered with the cold. and were white with snow this morning. the pack train and escort came in at 4 P.M cold and hungry. tired and weary. exposed without tents or shelter during the night
Wednesday Dec 27 1865
A Clear morning. still & very cold soon clouded up, and assumed a more dreary appearance than usual
Thusday Dec 28 1865
The night was one of those very clear & frosty nights, snow creaking under foot. the steady step of the Sentinel could be heard all over camp

  The pack train with a usual escort was sent to Camp Curry to obtain grain for the animals if possible. We had plenty of wild hay. badly frostbitten, Yet our animals were becoming poorer and poorer every day

107
We have had no news from the outside world for over a month.  Arrangements had been made for a semimonthly express between Camp Curry and Camp Watson, but the expressman left Camp Curry a month ago and has not returned

   A detacht of men had been sent out from Camp Curry a few days ago but they found the snow so deep in the Mts that they were obliged to return.  They reported finding the trail of the Expressman as far as they went and they think he passed over the Mountains before the route was entirely obstructed
   Another detachment is now out and expect to make the trip on Snoe [sic] shoes

Friday Dec 29 1865
The morning bright and biting cold the frost hanging about an inch thick upon every brush and blade of grass.  In the afternoon it became cloudy and Commenced snowing fine sifting snow. and a little before sundown we had one of he severest wind & snow squalls I ever saw anywhere.  It came in the form of a perfect whirligust from the West:  Lieuts Bowen and Applegate and myself were down the River South Easterly about 2 miles hunting rabbits. which appeared to be very

108
Monday January  1 1866
The first new years day ever passed by white men in Harney Lake Vally.  day pleasant and bright.  light wind from S.S.W. rather warm, snow settled down to  5 or 6 inches deep, permission was given to all hands to go rabbit hunting. which at this time is conducted by the troops with great success

  Fired a national salute today with our Mountain howitzer.

Tuesday Jan 2 1866
Last night was one of those clear and cold nights peculiar to a high mountain lattitude [sic].  the silent tread of the Sentinel could be distinctly heard as he paced to and fro over the creaking snow, sometimes walking an [sic] at other times running to keep themselves warm.  orders had been previously Given to change guard every hour and oftener if necessary  The morning is calm and sun bright all day snow settling.

  The Pack train and escort arrived at 4 P.M. and the Corpl in command had reported a cold time and that two of the men had frozen their feet quite badly.

Wed Jan 3 1866
cold as usual, clear day. wind North

numerous in that direction.

   We saw an appearance of a storm coming and having killed about a dozen rabbits we set out for Camp hoping to reach there. but the storm bust upon us when about ½ mile away in a perfect fury.  The wind blew a complete hurricane and the snow filed [sic] the air. and it was with difficulty that we could keep our feet.  We could not see 25 steps before us.  the storm lasted about ½ hour during which time Bowen & myself managed keep together, but we lost Applegate and he had about half of our rabbits. when the storm blowed over we discovered him about 50 yards off behind the thick sage, and we soon after  reached Camp

Saturday Dec 30 1865
Morning still and very cold. but a heavy west wind soon sprung up and during the day the snow flew in perfect clouds.
Sunday Dec 31 1865
Morning bright and clear. light east wind. day fair but cold. general muster and inspection day

[right margin cut off in duplicating the page]
Thursday Jan 4 1866
Night cold as usual, cloudy   Light East wind
Friday Jan  5 1866

  With 12 men I set out today to the timbered Mts North of the vally for the pu[rpose?] of securing a log of square timber to saw into plank for a fla[t] Boat to navigate the River and La[ke] in the early spring when the water will be high. and when we will hav[e] no other means of transportation 
   We steered across the sage valley nearly north and at 15 miles cam[ped] at a small branch at the foot of the Mts.  Snow about 1 ½ inches deep or 6 inches deeper than at Cam[p] Wright. on very nearly the same [?line?]
   A cold N.E wind blew all day alm[ost] direct in our faces

Saturday Jan 6 1866
Set out early this morning. proceede[d] up the canyon about 3 miles findi[ng] no available timber. and the snow rapidly increasing in depth as we advanced, we therefore returned & camped late in the P.M. at th[e] place we had left in the morning tired & weary. having wallow[ed] through the snow all day

   Cold wind from N.E. [&] becoming colder as night set in
